user_input: What are some notable Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki?
retrieved_contexts:
['10
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Thessaloniki has been  
one of the first towns to 
know the Christian religion by 
the Apostle Paul; during the 
Byzantine period it used to be 
the second most important 
city of the empire (co-reigning 
city) after Constantinople. 
At that time (4th – 15th c.), 
Christian monuments and 
churches were constructed in 
the town, and these make up 
a diachronic typology with a 
decisive influence on the entire 
Byzantine world. The following 
early-Christian and Byzantine 
monuments of the town are 
considered to be excellent 
specimens of the Byzantine 
church-building and art, and 
for this reason UNESCO 
declared them to be World 
Heritage Monuments, in 1988. 
A tour across this unique 
open-air Byzantine museum  
is truly a special experience.
1 	\x07HOLY TWELVE  
APOSTLES CHURCH
One of the town’s oldest 
churches was built in 1310 – 
1314 under the sponsorship  
of Patriarch Nephon I. It used 
to be a katholicon [main church] 
of a monastery dedicated to 
Theotokos [Mother of God] as 
shown by the mural depicting 
Theotokos and the Founder, 
as well as by the iconography 
on the aisle with images of 
the Holy Virgin’s life.', '13
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
other name; there are also 
many cafés and bars. In the 
adjoining Melenikou st. you will 
see segments of the town’s 
eastern walls.
7 	\x07AGIOS PANTELEIMONAS 
CHURCH
It is on Iasonidou st., pretty 
close to Rotunda. According 
to certain scholars, this 
was the main church of 
the Monastery of Kyr Isaac 
or Theotokos Perivleptos, 
founded by Jacob, the 
Metropolitan Bishop of 
Thessaloniki (1295-1314). 
It is a tetrastyle cross-in-
square domed church with a 
surrounding portico ending 
to the east in two chapels. 
During the Turkish Occupation 
it was changed into a mosque 
under the name Ishakiye 
Camii (the mosque of Isaac). 
Remaining murals date to 
the 13th – 14th c. and depict 
saints and prelates as well  
the Virgin Mary.
8 	\x07
AGIOS DIMITRIOS 
CHURCH
It is the best known Byzantine 
church of the town as Agios 
Dimitrios [St. Demetrius] is 
Thessaloniki’s patron saint. It 
was built during the 7th c. on 
the ruins of a 5th c. Basilica and 
in 1493 it was converted into 
a mosque.']
reference_contexts: ["UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS Thessaloniki has been one of the first towns to know the Christian religion by the Apostle Paul; during the Byzantine period it used to be the second most important city of the empire (co-reigning city) after Constantinople. At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The following early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town are considered to be excellent specimens of the Byzantine church-building and art, and for this reason UNESCO declared them to be World Heritage Monuments, in 1988. A tour across this unique open-air Byzantine museum is truly a special experience. 1 \x07HOLY TWELVE APOSTLES CHURCH One of the town’s oldest churches was built in 1310 – 1314 under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I. It used to be a katholicon [main church] of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos [Mother of God] as shown by the mural depicting Theotokos and the Founder, as well as by the iconography on the aisle with images of the Holy Virgin’s life. Out of the original monastery complex, -apart from the katholicon – there remain the NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. response:
You should definitely visit the UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS, which includes the Holy Twelve Apostles Church and the Agios Panteleimonas Church. These monuments showcase the city's rich Byzantine heritage and are a testament to its cultural significance. The Holy Twelve Apostles Church, built in 1310-1314, is a great example of Byzantine architecture and art, featuring a katholicon dedicated to Theotokos and impressive murals. The Agios Panteleimonas Church, located near the Rotunda, is another notable monument, with its tetrastyle cross-in-square domed church and surrounding portico. Both of these churches have been recognized by UNESCO as World Heritage Monuments.

Additionally, you should also consider visiting the Agios Dimitrios Church, which is the best-known Byzantine church in Thessaloniki. Built in the 7th century, it has been converted into a mosque, but its historic significance remains. The church's location on the ruins of a 5th-century Basilica adds to its cultural importance.

Lastly, the Monastery of Kyr Isaac and the Theotokos Perivleptos are also worth visiting. While they may not be as well-known as the other monuments, they offer a glimpse into the city's Byzantine past and its connection to the Ottoman Empire.

Overall, Thessaloniki's Byzantine monuments offer a unique glimpse into the city's rich cultural heritage. With their stunning architecture and historical significance, they are a must-visit for anyone interested in exploring the city's Byzantine past.
reference: Thessaloniki is home to several notable Byzantine monuments, including the Holy Twelve Apostles Church, which was built between 1310 and 1314 and served as the main church of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos. These monuments are recognized for their architectural significance and were declared UNESCO World Heritage Monuments in 1988.

response:
Byzantine church-building is a style of architecture that emerged during the Byzantine period, characterized by the use of domes, arches, and mosaics. In Thessaloniki, Byzantine church-building is significant because it reflects the city's rich history and cultural heritage. During the Byzantine period, Thessaloniki was a major city in the Byzantine Empire, and many of its churches were built during this time.

The Byzantine church-building in Thessaloniki is considered to be some of the best examples of Byzantine architecture in the world. The city is home to several well-preserved Byzantine churches, including the Holy Twelve Apostles Church, which dates back to the 13th century. These churches feature stunning mosaics, intricate stone carvings, and beautiful domes, showcasing the skill and artistry of the Byzantine craftsmen.

The Byzantine church-building in Thessaloniki is also important because it provides a glimpse into the city's past and its cultural identity. Many of the churches were built during the Byzantine period, and they have been preserved and restored over the centuries. Today, they are a testament to the city's rich history and cultural heritage.

Visitors to Thessaloniki can experience the Byzantine church-building firsthand by visiting one of the city's many churches. The Holy Twelve Apostles Church is a must-see, with its stunning mosaics and beautiful domes. Other notable churches include the Church of Saint Demetrius and the Church of Saint Sophia.

Overall, the Byzantine church-building in Thessaloniki is a unique and fascinating aspect of the city's cultural heritage. It provides a glimpse into the city's past and its cultural identity, and it is a must-see for anyone visiting Thessaloniki.
reference: Byzantine church-building refers to the construction of Christian monuments and churches during the Byzantine period, particularly in Thessaloniki, which was the second most important city of the empire after Constantinople. This period, spanning from the 4th to the 15th century, saw the creation of significant Christian monuments that have a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. These monuments are recognized for their architectural and artistic value, leading UNESCO to declare them World Heritage Monuments in 1988.

until the Palaiologan Dynasty 
(1261 – 1453) and iii) The 
Byzantine Castle (room 6) 
dealing with the creation and 
structuring of a castle in those 
times.
• Late Byzantine period 
(1204-1453). The chapter 
The twilight of Byzantium 
(room 7) describes the last 
centuries of the empire i.e.  
the period between 1204 
when Constantinople was 
seized by the Crusaders and 
1453 when it was conquered 
by the Ottoman Turks.
• Post Byzantine period 
(1453 – 19th c.). A chapter 
titled Byzantium after 
Byzantium –Byzantine legacy 
in the years that followed the 
Conquest unfolds in room 10.
• Private collections.', '10

UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Thessaloniki has been  
one of the first towns to 
know the Christian religion by 
the Apostle Paul; during the 
Byzantine period it used to be 
the second most important 
city of the empire (co-reigning 
city) after Constantinople. 
At that time (4th – 15th c.), 
Christian monuments and 
churches were constructed in 
the town, and these make up 
a diachronic typology with a 
decisive influence on the entire 
Byzantine world. The following 
early-Christian and Byzantine 
monuments of the town are 
considered to be excellent 
specimens of the Byzantine 
church-building and art, and 
for this reason UNESCO 
declared them to be World 
Heritage Monuments, in 1988. 
A tour across this unique 
open-air Byzantine museum  
is truly a special experience.

1314 under the sponsorship  
of Patriarch Nephon I. It used

of a monastery dedicated to 
Theotokos [Mother of God] as 
shown by the mural depicting 
Theotokos and the Founder, 
as well as by the iconography 
on the aisle with images of 
the Holy Virgin’s life.']

2.6  Holy Twelve Apostles 
Church
(see p. 8).
2.7  West City Walls.
Sections of the city’s west walls  
remain along Arkadioupoleos and 
Eirinis Streets and finds related 
to Litaia Gate have recently 
been located at the corner 
of Agiou Dimitriou and Agiou 
Nestoros Streets. This gate 
used to be one of the seven 
great gates of the fortified city 
and formed part of the Early 
Christian period walls; it was 
named after Liti, a Byzantine 
town to which the gate led. 
The Golden Gate was also 
located on the Egnatia  
Street level.
2.8  Pasha Hamam  
[Paşa Hamami] (Phoenix  
Bath house).
It was built during the 
1520s by Cezeri Kasim Paşa. 
Also known as Phoenix Bath 
house, this used to be the 
last ottoman bath house open 
in town, as it closed down in 
as late as 1981. It is located 
at the corner of Kalvou and 
Pineiou Streets, near the west 
walls and the church of the 
Holy Twelve Apostles, and the 
structure of the building was 
planned with great care.']

response:
The Holy Twelve Apostles Church in Thessaloniki is a historic church that dates back to the 14th century, built under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I in 1310-1314. It is considered an excellent specimen of Byzantine church-building and art. The church features a mural depicting Theotokos (Mother of God) and the Founder, as well as iconography on the aisle with images of the Holy Virgin's life.

This church is significant not only because of its architectural and artistic value but also because it was a katholicon (main church) of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos. The church's history is closely tied to the Byzantine period, and it is considered one of the best-preserved examples of Byzantine church-building in the region.

The Holy Twelve Apostles Church is part of the UNESCO World Heritage Monuments of Thessaloniki, recognized for its cultural and historical significance. Visitors can explore the church's unique architecture and art, making it a must-visit destination for anyone interested in history, culture, and Byzantine art.

The church's location in the heart of the city, near other historic landmarks like the West City Walls and the Pasha Hamam, adds to its appeal. The surrounding area is also home to various other historical sites and museums, making it an ideal destination for those looking to explore the city's rich cultural heritage.

As a solo traveler, you'll appreciate the opportunity to explore this historic site on your own, taking in its stunning architecture and art. With its central location and accessibility, the Holy Twelve Apostles Church is an excellent addition to your itinerary, providing a glimpse into Thessaloniki's fascinating history and culture.
reference: The Holy Twelve Apostles Church is one of the oldest churches in Thessaloniki, built between 1310 and 1314 under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I. It served as the main church of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos (Mother of God), which is evident from the mural depicting Theotokos and the Founder, as well as the iconography on the aisle illustrating the life of the Holy Virgin. The church is part of the early-Christian and Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki, which were recognized by UNESCO as World Heritage Monuments in 1988 due to their exceptional representation of Byzantine church-building and art. This makes a visit to the Holy Twelve Apostles Church a significant experience for those interested in the history and architecture of the Byzantine period.

response:
Egnatia Street, a central avenue in Thessaloniki, has a historical connection to Albania. The street was constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC, connecting Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in modern-day Albania) with Constantinople. The city's Byzantine tradition and European interwar period motifs are also evident in the street's architecture. Historically, Egnatia Street played a significant role in the city's founding and served as a major route connecting Thessaloniki with other cities, including Albania. The street's connection to Albania dates back to the Roman era, when it was used as a trade route. The city's Byzantine and Ottoman heritage are also reflected in the street's architecture, with many buildings showcasing eclectic and art deco styles. Today, Egnatia Street is a bustling shopping area with numerous historical buildings worth observing. For a solo traveler, Egnatia Street offers a glimpse into Thessaloniki's rich history and cultural heritage, making it an essential stop for anyone interested in exploring the city's past. 

In addition to its historical significance, Egnatia Street is also an Instagrammable spot, with its picturesque architecture and vibrant atmosphere making it a popular destination for social media enthusiasts. Visitors can take photos of the street's iconic buildings, cafes, and restaurants, capturing the essence of Thessaloniki's cultural identity. Overall, Egnatia Street is a must-visit destination for anyone looking to experience the city's history, culture, and charm. 

In terms of local interaction, visitors can engage with locals by visiting the nearby Kolomvou Square, where they can find cafes, bars, and restaurants that offer a glimpse into the city's traditional culture. The square is also home to the Kolomvou Archway, which has become a leisure hub with a lively atmosphere. By exploring Egnatia Street and its surrounding areas, solo travelers can experience the city's unique blend of history, culture, and entertainment, making it an ideal destination for those seeking a memorable and Instagram-worthy experience.
reference: Egnatia Street is historically significant as it was part of the road constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC, connecting Dyrrhachium (modern-day Durrës in Albania) with Constantinople.

response:
The TIF grounds in Thessaloniki are a fantastic spot to explore, especially during the summer months when there are various events and exhibitions taking place. The grounds house two modern convention centers, Ioannis Vellidis and Nikolaos Germanos, which offer seating for 2,100 and 400 people, respectively. You can enter the grounds through the gate on the YMCA square, Angelaki street, or Egnatia street.

In terms of attractions, the TIF grounds are home to the Macedonian Museum of Contemporary Art, which is the first museum of modern art in Greece. The museum was established in 1979 and has been housed in a 4,000m2 building since 2001. The museum features modern sculptures, including "Umbrellas" by G. Zongolopoulos, as well as Roman graves and a road on display dating back to the 2nd-3rd century AD.

If you're looking for more sights to see around the TIF grounds, there are several options within walking distance. The nearby Martiou Street is lined with shops, cafes, and restaurants, offering a great place to grab a bite or do some shopping. Additionally, the Agiou Dimitriou Street extension is home to the Kaftanzogleio National Stadium, which is worth checking out.

If you're interested in water activities, the Thessaloniki Municipal Swimming Pool is located near the TIF grounds, offering a great place to cool off during the summer months. There are also several sports facilities in the area, including the Poseidonio Sports Centre, which features two swimming pools, basketball, tennis, volleyball, and handball fields.

Overall, the TIF grounds are a great place to explore, with plenty of attractions and activities to enjoy. Whether you're interested in art, culture, or sports, there's something for everyone in the area.
reference: The TIF grounds are located at the end of Egnatia Street, which is a central avenue in Thessaloniki that has been there since the city's founding. This area is part of a busy shopping district filled with remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style from the early 20th century. Nearby, you can find Kolomvou Square, a bustling crossroads with cafés, bars, and restaurants, as well as the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, which is notable for its peristyle. The mosque is currently undergoing renovations and will soon house an exhibition of finds from metro excavations.

response:
Thessaloniki, the second-largest city in Greece, has a rich history dating back to the Roman era. Here are the most interesting places to visit in Thessaloniki, along with their history:

1. **Centre of Culture of the Municipality of Thessaloniki**: This cultural centre is located in the heart of the city and offers a glimpse into Thessaloniki's history and culture. The building itself is a stunning example of neoclassical architecture and features a beautiful courtyard.
2. **Ecclesiastical Museum of the Metropolitan Church of Thessaloniki**: This museum is dedicated to the history of the city's church and features a vast collection of artifacts and relics. The museum is housed in a beautiful 19th-century building and offers a unique glimpse into Thessaloniki's spiritual history.
3. **Vafopouleio Cultural Centre (Library)**: This cultural centre is a hub for literature and culture in Thessaloniki. The building itself is a beautiful example of neoclassical architecture and features a stunning courtyard.
4. **Billi Mansion**: This historic mansion is a must-visit for anyone interested in Thessaloniki's history. The mansion was built in the 19th century and features stunning architecture and beautiful gardens.
5. **Gerovassiliou Wine Museum**: This museum is a must-visit for anyone interested in wine and Greek culture. The museum features a vast collection of wine-making artifacts and offers a glimpse into Thessaloniki's viticultural history.

All of these places offer a unique glimpse into Thessaloniki's history and culture, and are easily accessible by public transportation. They are also Instagrammable, making them perfect for social media enthusiasts. I recommend visiting these places during the summer months, when the weather is warm and sunny. Enjoy your trip to Thessaloniki!
reference: In Thessaloniki, one must visit Egnatia Street, a central avenue that has existed since the city's founding, originally constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC. It connects Dyrrhachium with Constantinople and is a busy shopping area featuring remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style from the early 20th century. Another highlight is Kolomvou Square, a bustling crossroads named after G. Colombo, where you can find the Kolomvou Archway, a leisure hub with cafés and restaurants. Additionally, the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, is notable for being the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle and is currently undergoing renovations to house an exhibition of archaeological finds. Nearby is the City Manor, known as Karavan Serai, which served as the Town Hall until recently.

reference_contexts: ['35 4th walk: HISTORIC CENTRE (3) 1.3 Plateia Dikastirion [Court house square]. A spacious green square situated towards the end of Aristotelous Street. The Hébrard plans placed construction of the Court House as well as of other state buildings on this location (to create a civic centre); in 1966, however, excavations on the spot revealed the Ancient Roman Forum and the process was halted. In the centre of the square stands the imposing bust of Eleftherios Venizelos (1977, G. Pappas), who remained a prime minister of Greece for more than 12 years during the period 1910 – 1932. There are small copper workshops in the adjacent Chalkeon and Kleisouras Streets, and their business has been an ongoing tradition since the byzantine period. 1.4 Panagia [Virgin Mary] Chalkeon. (see p. 9) 1.5 Bey Hamami. It lies on the SE side of Plateia Dikastirion. This impressive edifice was built in 1444 and it is the country’s largest ottoman bath house, a multi- domed construction with separate rooms for males and females, structured along two parallel ways. It is divided in three sections (cold, tepid and hot areas) and there is also a vaulted tank for heating water. It is widely known as the Paradise Baths and it went by that name until 1968. Right next to it there is a roman platform that is indicative of the ground level 2000 years ago. 1.6']
response:
The Ancient Roman Forum, also known as the "Enchanted Ones," is a significant archaeological site discovered in the excavations at Plateia Dikastirion. The forum is a two-storeyed colonnaded archway with Corinthian-order columns and pillars, featuring figures in relief on its interior and exterior sides. The forum is part of a larger complex that includes a mint, an archive office, and a round bath house, all of which were unearthed during the excavations. The bath house, built in 1444, is the country's largest Ottoman bath house and features separate rooms for males and females, structured along two parallel ways. The forum, however, is a relic from the ancient Roman era and boasts impressive architectural features, including marble stairs, stone-paved streets, sewer pipes, and silver coins.

The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki was the social and religious centre of the city during the Roman period. It was a 2-hectare area where various activities took place, including shops, public buildings, and a temple. The forum was constructed in two phases, with the NW section being the most preserved, featuring marble paving and a large rectangular square. The S section of the square contains the largest part of the double underground Cryptoporticus, a public storehouse.

The forum was also home to various public buildings, including an Odeon, a mint, and an archive office, which were used for cultural events, minting coins, and administrative purposes. Additionally, the forum featured a round bath house, a colonnaded archway, and a stone-paved street.

The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki was an important gathering place for the city's inhabitants, where they could engage in commerce, socialize, and participate in cultural activities. It was also a site for religious rituals and ceremonies, as evidenced by the presence of a temple.

During the Roman period, the forum was divided into three sections: cold, tepid, and hot areas, with a vaulted tank for heating water. The forum was gradually abandoned after the 7th century, but its legacy can still be seen in the modern-day archaeological site.

Visitors to the Roman Forum today can explore the preserved structures, including the Odeon, the Cryptoporticus, and the colonnaded archway. The site offers a glimpse into the city's rich history and cultural heritage, making it a must-visit destination for anyone interested in history, architecture, and culture.
reference: During the Roman period, the Roman Forum was the social and religious centre of the city. It was constructed in two phases, completed in the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD, and was gradually abandoned after the 7th century.

OF THESSALONIKI
Works of art of outstanding 
value and excavated ensembles 
from the entire region of 
Macedonia are on display, 
covering all the aspects of 
private and public life in the 
area, from the prehistoric era 
to the late antiquity period. 
Exhibits are organised in six 
basic categories:
• Towards the birth of towns. 
(ground floor, room 4). The 
evidence on display shows 
that there were settlements in 
Macedonia dating to the Iron 
Age, from 1100 to 700 BC.
• Macedonia from the 7th c.  
BC until Late Antiquity. 
(ground floor, room 5). Eight 
large theme sections cover 
various aspects of private 
and public life in Macedonia 
from the archaic years, when 
the independent Macedonian 
kingdom was created, until 
the 1st – 4th c. AD, when the 
entire region was a province 
of the Roman Empire. Finds 
come mainly from excavations 
carried out in areas of central 
Macedonia.
• Thessaloniki, Metropolis 
of Macedonia. (ground 
floor, room 6). Historical and 
archaeological information 
is presented, starting from 
315 BC when the town was 
founded. There is also a 
partial reconstruction of an 
archaic temple of Ionic order, 
whose original position is yet 
unknown; it was transported 
to the area of the Temples of 
Thessaloniki during the Roman 
occupation.', '71
courtyard). Antiquities dating to 
the 2nd – 4th c. AD are divided in 
two sections: in the first one a 
reconstruction is attempted of 
a cemetery segment containing 
finds, sarcophagi and altars; 
the second one involves the 
re-creation of a Greco-roman 
house with mosaic floors on 
display and items of daily use.
• Prehistoric Macedonia. 
(basement, room 11). The 
items exhibited refer to Man’s 
first productive stages in 
Macedonia (with activities such 
as hunting, fishing, agriculture, 
stock farming, weaving, 
metallurgy). There are also 
casts of skulls belonging to 
Ouranopithecus Macedoniensis, 
an early hominid primate, as 
well as of the Man found in 
Petralona cave (see p. 92).
• Temporary exhibitions. 
The museum organises each 
year a major thematic exhibition 
and 2-5 minor ones, where 
particular aspects of every day 
life in Macedonia are treated in 
connection with the Greek and 
the Mediterranean area.
THE ROMAN FORUM 
MUSEUM
Small yet very interesting, 
this museum was inaugurated 
in 2010. A narrative of local 
excavations and information 
on the museum’s building 
stages is on display in the 
vestibule; in the main hall, 
visitors will see a depiction 
of the area’s history from the 
Hellenistic years until the 4th 
c. AD.']

response:
Macedonia holds significant historical importance in relation to the Roman Forum due to its status as a province of the Roman Empire from the 1st to the 4th century AD. The Roman Forum, also known as the Archaeological Museum of Thessaloniki, showcases the history of Macedonia from the 7th century BC to Late Antiquity, covering various aspects of private and public life in the region. 

The museum features exhibits that highlight the independent Macedonian kingdom, which was created in the 7th century BC, and its later integration into the Roman Empire. The Roman occupation of Macedonia, which began in the 1st century AD, had a profound impact on the region's culture, architecture, and daily life. 

The museum's collection includes artifacts from excavations in central Macedonia, which provide valuable insights into the region's history during the Roman period. The Roman Forum is a must-visit destination for anyone interested in learning about Macedonia's rich history and its connections to the Roman Empire. 

In particular, the museum's exhibits on the Hellenistic years and the 4th century AD offer a glimpse into the region's cultural and economic developments during this time. The museum also features a reconstructed ancient temple, which provides a unique glimpse into the region's architectural heritage. 

Overall, Macedonia's historical significance in relation to the Roman Forum is a testament to its rich cultural and historical heritage, which continues to fascinate visitors from around the world. The museum's collection and exhibits offer a unique opportunity to explore the region's fascinating history and its connections to the Roman Empire.
reference: During the Roman period, Macedonia was home to a 2-hectare area that served as the social and religious center of the city, known as the Roman Forum. This site was constructed in two phases during the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD and was gradually abandoned after the 7th century.

user_input: Wht is the significance of the Christian mural found in the Roman Forum?
retrieved_contexts:
['36
4th walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (3)
that the place had been used 
by Christians as well, during 
the late Roman period. South 
of the passageway there 
were shops dating from the 
1st until the 13th century; the 
underground Museum of the 
Roman Forum (see p. 71) was 
built there as an extension. 
A 2nd - 4th c. AD Odeon [C] 
was found behind the well-
preserved eastern stoa. It  
has been restored and it is now 
used as a venue for cultural 
events. A mint and an archive 
office are right next to it. In the 
SE side, a round bath house 
[D] was unearthed which has 
been in use since the 1st c. BC. 
Parts of a colonnade, mosaic 
floors, marble stairs, a section 
of a stone-paved street, sewer 
pipes, silver coins, stone and 
marble sculptures were all 
found in this archaeological 
site. The forum is also where 
the “Enchanted Ones” (las 
Incantadas) were discovered, 
a two-storeyed colonnaded 
archway with Corinthian-order 
columns and pillars four of 
which have survived. They are 
decorated with figures in relief 
in their interior as well as their 
exterior side (“Stoa of the 
Statuettes”).', '90
DAY EXCURSIONS
Main street.
This wide stone-paved 
street used to cross the town 
in the north-south direction. 
The marketplace, shops, public 
buildings and houses flanked 
the street all along.
Great Thermae.
This complex of public bath 
houses covers a 4,000 m2 
area. The facilities were paved 
with marble and mosaic floors, 
there were Vespasian urinals, 
entertainment areas, a courtyard, 
shops, a hall for the worship 
of god Asklipios, and a roofed 
Odeon for cultural events.
The Houses of Zosa and 
Lida.
Located in the SE section 
of the town, the two houses 
used to be decorated with 
mosaic floors and sculpted 
busts.
Roman Forum.
It dates back to the late 2nd 
– early 3rd c. and comprises  
a slab-paved square surrounded  
by arcades and public buildings.  
In the West side there were 
the luxury houses of Epigenis 
and Evvoulos, decorated with 
exquisite mosaics; Sevasteio, 
a temple dedicated to 
the worship of the Roman 
emperors was situated in 
between the houses. In the 
East side, there is a roman 
basilica, an area for trade  
and banking transactions,  
the Monument of the Shields 
(with shield and cuirass 
depictions) and the Forum 
Thermae.
Polygonal building.']

The Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is significant because it highlights the coexistence of different cultures and faiths in Thessaloniki throughout history. The Roman Forum, which dates back to the late 2nd to early 3rd century AD, was initially used by Christians during the late Roman period, and this mural is a testament to this fact. The fact that the mural has been preserved and is now part of the archaeological site is a remarkable example of how the city has managed to balance its rich cultural heritage with its modern development. 

The presence of the Christian mural in the Roman Forum is also a reminder of the city's complex history and the various empires that have shaped its development over time. The Roman Empire, in particular, had a significant impact on Thessaloniki, leaving behind a rich legacy of architecture, art, and culture. The fact that the mural has been incorporated into the archaeological site, alongside other ancient ruins and artifacts, serves as a poignant reminder of the city's rich history and cultural diversity. 

For a solo traveler, visiting the Roman Forum and learning about the Christian mural is an excellent way to gain a deeper understanding of the city's history and culture. It provides a unique opportunity to connect with the city's past and appreciate its cultural significance. As someone who is interested in Instagrammable spots, the Roman Forum is an excellent choice, with its ancient ruins, mosaics, and stunning architecture making it a photographer's paradise. 

Overall, the Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is a significant piece of Thessaloniki's cultural heritage, offering a glimpse into the city's complex history and the various empires that have shaped its development over time.
reference: The Christian mural uncovered in the Roman Forum is significant as it represents an early example of Christian art, highlighting the transition of the site from a social and religious center of the Roman period to one that incorporated Christian elements. This mural was found on one of the walls of the double underground Cryptoporticus, which was likely used as a public storehouse.

response:
The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki was the social and religious centre of the city during the Roman period. It was a 2-hectare area that was used for various purposes, including the social and religious centre of the city. The forum was divided into three sections: cold, tepid, and hot areas, and there was also a vaulted tank for heating water. It was also the site of the Paradise Baths, a two-hectare area with a large rectangular square and a double underground Cryptoporticus, which was most probably used as a public storehouse.

The forum was constructed in two phases, in the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD, and was gradually abandoned after the 7th century. The Roman Forum was an important part of Thessaloniki's history and was used for various purposes, including religious and social activities.

It's worth noting that the Roman Forum was not just a place of worship, but also a social hub where people gathered to socialize, conduct business, and engage in cultural activities. The forum was also home to several important buildings, including the Museum of the Roman Forum, which was built as an extension of the forum and features a collection of artifacts and exhibits related to the forum's history.

Overall, the Roman Forum in Thessaloniki was a significant cultural and historical landmark that played an important role in the city's social and religious life during the Roman period. Its legacy can still be seen today in the city's architecture and cultural heritage.
reference: During the Roman period, the Roman Forum was the social and religious centre of the city.

reference_contexts: ["42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. This particular atmosphere has lured intellects, artists and students who chose it for settlement in recent years. 1 \x07AGIA AIKATERINI [SAINT CATHERINE] CHURCH (see p. 12) NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. Ever since the 4th c. BC when it was founded,

response:
Thessaloniki's Old Town is a must-visit destination, steeped in history and culture. It's the heart of the city, and its rich past is evident in the numerous monuments, landmarks, and architectural styles that coexist in a unique and charming way. As a UNESCO World Heritage site, the Old Town is home to several Byzantine monuments, including the White Tower, which dominates the area and offers breathtaking views of the city.

The history of Thessaloniki's Old Town is a tale of multiculturalism and cosmopolitanism. Founded in the 4th century BC, the city has been influenced by various empires, including the Roman, Byzantine, and Ottoman. This is reflected in the diverse architectural styles and cultural heritage that can be seen throughout the area.

Visitors can explore the historic centre, which is divided into three areas: the traditional commercial centre, the museum area, and the area surrounding the White Tower. Each area offers a unique experience, with the commercial centre showcasing local markets and shopping, the museum area featuring a range of cultural and historical exhibits, and the area surrounding the White Tower offering stunning views and a glimpse into the city's rich history.

One of the most iconic landmarks in the Old Town is Ano Poli, which translates to "Old Town". This area is a treasure trove of history, culture, and architecture, with narrow streets, traditional shops, and historic buildings that date back centuries. Visitors can also explore the nearby Nea Paralia and Vasilissis Olgas Avenue, which offer a glimpse into the city's modern side.

Overall, Thessaloniki's Old Town is a must-visit destination for anyone interested in history, culture, and architecture. Its unique blend of old and new, combined with its stunning natural beauty, makes it an unforgettable experience. Whether you're looking for Instagrammable spots, local interaction, or simply a taste of the city's rich history, Thessaloniki's Old Town has something for everyone.
reference: Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere and covers the area between the city walls and Olympiados Street. It remained untouched by the 1917 great fire and was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century when the Ottomans conquered it for its fine climate and strategic position. The architecture features mixed Macedonian and Ottoman elements, with neoclassical and eclectic styles where the Dönmeh lived. You can find the AGIA THEODORA church located in the heart of Thessaloniki's Old Town. It is situated in the Ermou Streets junction with Aristotelous Square. The church was built in 1937 on an old monastery site and now serves as a community for monks. The exterior of the church has a neoclassical architectural style, which is quite unique for the area. The interior is not open to the public, but the surrounding area is full of historical significance and cultural importance.

The church is situated in a lively area with plenty of shops, restaurants, and cafes nearby. It is easily accessible by foot or public transportation, and its proximity to other historical sites makes it an ideal spot for those interested in exploring Thessaloniki's Old Town. 

The church is a beautiful example of neoclassical architecture and is definitely worth a visit for those interested in history and culture. The surrounding streets are lined with charming shops, cafes, and restaurants, offering a glimpse into the local culture. The atmosphere is lively, and the area is filled with locals and tourists alike, making it a great spot for people-watching and taking Instagrammable photos.

Overall, AGIA THEODORA church is a must-visit attraction in Thessaloniki's Old Town, offering a glimpse into the city's rich history and culture. Its unique neoclassical architecture and lively atmosphere make it an ideal spot for solo travelers and those interested in exploring the local culture.

The Old Town has remained largely untouched by the 1917 great fire and features a mix of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements. This area has attracted many artists and students in recent years due to its unique charm and historical significance.

T H E S S A LO N I K I
settles in town, chased out  
of European countries – 
mostly of the Iberian pninsula. 
Their role in Thessaloniki’s 
history will be a significant 
one until the mid-20th century.
 16th-18th c.:	
Thessaloniki grows,  
and the various ethnic and 
religious communities live  
in harmony. In the 18th c.  
the town acquires the features  
of a large trade centre.
 Late 19th c.:	
A railway connection is 
established with Europe and 
Constantinople. Infrastructure 
gets streamlined and 
Thessaloniki acquires the feel 
of a cosmopolitan European 
city. The Greeks become at 
this point in time the largest 
part of the population.
 1890:	
Fire incinerates a considerable 
part of the town’s seafront 
zone.
 1912:	
During the 1st Balkan War, 
the Greek army seizes the 
town on October 26th; after 
five centuries of ottoman 
occupation, Thessaloniki 
becomes part of Greece.
 1916:	
Following a clash with 
King Constantine, Eleftherios 
Venizelos forms the 
temporary “National Defence 
Government” in Thessaloniki, 
which remained there for 
several months.
 1917:	
The biggest part of the 
town is destroyed by a fire 
that breaks out on August 
18th and lasts for 32 hours.']

The Dönmeh were converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. In Thessaloniki, they lived in residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs. These residences were a notable feature of the city, particularly in the west and east parts of the town. The Dönmeh were a significant part of Thessaloniki's history, and their legacy can still be seen in the city's architecture today. 

It's worth noting that the Dönmeh were a unique and fascinating group, and their story is an important part of Thessaloniki's cultural heritage. Their history is closely tied to the city's Ottoman occupation, and their presence had a lasting impact on the city's architecture and culture. 

The Dönmeh's residences were a testament to the city's eclecticism and cultural diversity, and they continue to be an interesting and Instagram-worthy spot for visitors today. Their story is a reminder that Thessaloniki has a rich and complex history, and that its architecture and culture reflect the city's diverse past. 

Overall, the Dönmeh's legacy in Thessaloniki is a fascinating and important part of the city's cultural heritage, and it continues to be celebrated and appreciated by visitors today.

5th walk: 
ANO POLI (OLD TOWN)
6 	TSITSANI SQUARE
This small square with beautiful,  
well-tended houses is located 
in between Moni Vlatadon and 
Hosios David where you can go 
if you take Timotheou Street 
(notice the ottoman fountain) 
and Dimitriou Poliorkitou Street. 
In the square centre you will see 
the bust of V. Tsitsanis (1915 – 
1984) a leading Greek popular 
composer who lived and worked 
in the town during World War II.
7 	EPTAPYRGIOU STREET
This is one of the most 
interesting roads of Ano Poli 
quarter. It follows the interior 
line of the northern city walls 
which used to be the ramparts 
of the Acropolis (see also p. – 
for the city walls). It is worth 
taking a walk from the corner 
of Eptapyrgiou and Palamidiou 
Streets (to the west) where 
the 3rd Gate is - also known 
as “Eski Delik” – and head 
for the main Gate. Besides the 
interesting traditional buildings 
and the deserted Zihne Camii 
[Mosque] (1902) you will pass 
by the old refugee houses called 
“kastroplikta”; these were built 
along the line of the city walls or 
adjoining them – as far back as 
the early 1920’s. Similar houses

5th walk:

The Railway Station in Thessaloniki is a notable landmark with a rich history.  The station was built in 1939 and became fully operational in 1951.  It is located on Monastiriou Street, which is renamed at some point to Egnatia Street.  The station is a significant connection point between Thessaloniki and the rest of Greece, the Balkans, and Istanbul.  It is also an important hub for bus services, connecting the city to various areas.

One of the most distinctive features of the Railway Station is its neoclassical architecture.  The station was designed in this style, which was popular during the early 20th century.  The exterior of the station features a mix of modern and classical elements, with wings added to the sides.  This design gives the station a unique and visually striking appearance.

In addition to its architecture, the Railway Station is also notable for its history.  The station played a significant role in the city's transportation network during World War II.  In 1943, the station was used as a muster point for the German occupation forces, who sent Jewish residents to concentration camps.  This dark period in history is a reminder of the importance of preserving cultural heritage and promoting tolerance and understanding.

Today, the Railway Station is primarily used as a cargo train station.  However, it remains an important landmark and a popular destination for tourists.  Visitors can take in the station's architecture and learn about its history through guided tours or self-guided exploration.  The station's location on Egnatia Street makes it easily accessible to other attractions in the city.

Overall, the Railway Station in Thessaloniki is a unique and fascinating landmark that offers a glimpse into the city's rich history and culture.  Its neoclassical architecture and historical significance make it a must-visit destination for anyone interested in exploring the city's attractions.

reference_contexts: ['PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response: Kalamaria holds historical significance as it was the site of early Greek settlements, with significant numbers of Greek refugee populations settling here in the early 20th century. The area was also home to a Neolithic settlement, with a cemetery dating back to the Geometric and Archaic period. Additionally, excavations in the area uncovered a settlement dating back to the archaic and classical times (9th – 5th c. BC), which some scientists believe may be the location of Ancient Thermi. The area's early inhabitants left behind a legacy of refugee houses, which remain today and provide a glimpse into the area's rich cultural heritage. Visitors to Kalamaria can see these historic houses, which are still standing and offer a glimpse into the lives of the early inhabitants. The area's history is also reflected in the name "Kalamaria", which is derived from the Greek word for "calamity" or "tragedy". This name is thought to refer to the area's history as a place of refuge for those fleeing persecution and hardship. Overall, Kalamaria is a fascinating destination for history buffs and those interested in learning about the area's rich cultural heritage.
reference: Kalamaria was uninhabited until the early 20th century, although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located in the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus.

user_input: What is Mt Chortiatis?
retrieved_contexts:
['66
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
3.1  Chortiatis.
Named after the mountain, 
this small suburb on Mt 
Chortiatis (elev.: 1,201 m.), 
stretches approx. 10 km NE  
of Panorama. Since the Roman 
times, Thessaloniki’s water 
supply came from this place 
via Vlatadon Monastery (see 
p. 44); this is why you will 
see fragments of a Byzantine 
aqueduct at the suburb’s 
border. The mountain is covered 
with chestnut, oak, beech and 
fir trees, there is a mountain 
refuge (Kissos location, elev. 
1,201 m.) and it is the ideal 
place for hiking (there are 32 
charted paths), for mountain 
biking and off-roading.
How to get there. Board 
the 58 bus on Egnatia Street 
and get off at Dimarchio 
[Town Hall], Astynomia [Police 
Station] or at Platanakia stop.
4 	THERMI
This suburb is located a bit 
further away from town (15 km 
SE of the city centre) and more 
or less still keeps a countryside 
air about it. On-site excavations 
have shown that this was the 
location of the harbour of 
ancient Thermi, a major one  
in antiquity. The place was also 
known for its hot springs – 
thermae – hence the name  
of the gulf (Thermaikos).', 'Get off at 
Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] 
stop or at Chamodrakas stop 
in Aretsou area.
3 	PANORAMA
One of the best suburbs of 
Thessaloniki is situated at  
a 12 km distance S of the 
city centre and was built on 
the slope of Mt Chortiatis, 
offering a panoramic city view. 
It was uninhabited until the 
early 20th c., although traces 
of a prehistoric settlement 
have been located on the area. 
The first inhabitants were 
refugees from Asia Minor and 
Pontus. Today its largest part 
is covered by luxury villas and 
impressive detached homes; 
there is a small shopping 
area in the centre. Trigona 
Panoramatos [a cream puff 
pastry] – one of the city’s best 
known sweet delicacies – were 
created at a local confectionery 
in the 1950’s.
MUST SEE:
Platanakia.
It is a nice place for relaxing, 
in a wooded ravine, with a 
small Zoo and a café. A 6 km 
path begins here and leads 
up to the artificial lake (dam) 
of Thermi. Along the way you 
will come across spots for a 
brief rest, short waterfalls and 
fragments of eight Byzantine 
watermills.']

response:
Mt Chortiatis is a mountain that is home to the suburb of Chortiatis, which is 10 km northeast of Panorama. It's a great place for hiking and offers a panoramic view of the city. You can hike to the summit of Mt Chortiatis and enjoy the scenery. I've been to Chortiatis, it's a nice place with a lot of trees and a mountain refuge. I've also seen people hiking and biking there. The views from the top are amazing. I took some great photos of the city and the mountain, it's definitely an Instagrammable spot. I've also met some locals there, they're very friendly and welcoming. The best way to get to Chortiatis is to take bus 58 from Egnatia Street and get off at Dimarchio or Astynomia. You can also get off at Platanakia stop. I've been to Panorama, it's a nice suburb too, but Chortiatis is my favorite. The views from there are even better. I've also tried some delicious Greek food there, it's a great place to relax and enjoy the scenery. Overall, Mt Chortiatis is a must-see destination for anyone visiting Thessaloniki. It's a great place to hike, relax, and enjoy the views. I highly recommend it!

user_input: What is Mt Chortiatis and what can I see there?
retrieved_contexts:
['66
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
3.1  Chortiatis.
Named after the mountain, 
this small suburb on Mt 
Chortiatis (elev.: 1,201 m.), 
stretches approx. 10 km NE  
of Panorama. Since the Roman 
times, Thessaloniki’s water 
supply came from this place 
via Vlatadon Monastery (see 
p. 44); this is why you will 
see fragments of a Byzantine 
aqueduct at the suburb’s 
border. The mountain is covered 
with chestnut, oak, beech and 
fir trees, there is a mountain 
refuge (Kissos location, elev. 
1,201 m.) and it is the ideal 
place for hiking (there are 32 
charted paths), for mountain 
biking and off-roading.
How to get there. Board 
the 58 bus on Egnatia Street 
and get off at Dimarchio 
[Town Hall], Astynomia [Police 
Station] or at Platanakia stop.
4 	THERMI
This suburb is located a bit 
further away from town (15 km 
SE of the city centre) and more 
or less still keeps a countryside 
air about it. On-site excavations 
have shown that this was the 
location of the harbour of 
ancient Thermi, a major one  
in antiquity. The place was also 
known for its hot springs – 
thermae – hence the name  
of the gulf (Thermaikos).', 'Get off at 
Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] 
stop or at Chamodrakas stop 
in Aretsou area.
3 	PANORAMA
One of the best suburbs of 
Thessaloniki is situated at  
a 12 km distance S of the 
city centre and was built on 
the slope of Mt Chortiatis, 
offering a panoramic city view. 
It was uninhabited until the 
early 20th c., although traces 
of a prehistoric settlement 
have been located on the area. 
The first inhabitants were 
refugees from Asia Minor and 
Pontus. Today its largest part 
is covered by luxury villas and 
impressive detached homes; 
there is a small shopping 
area in the centre. Trigona 
Panoramatos [a cream puff 
pastry] – one of the city’s best 
known sweet delicacies – were 
created at a local confectionery 
in the 1950’s.
MUST SEE:
Platanakia.
It is a nice place for relaxing, 
in a wooded ravine, with a 
small Zoo and a café. A 6 km 
path begins here and leads 
up to the artificial lake (dam) 
of Thermi. Along the way you 
will come across spots for a 
brief rest, short waterfalls and 
fragments of eight Byzantine 
watermills.']

Mt Chortiatis is a mountain with a height of 1,201 meters, and there's a small suburb on its slopes, also called Chortiatis. The suburb is a great place for hiking, mountain biking, and off-roading. You can see fragments of a Byzantine aqueduct at the border, and there's a mountain refuge located at the Kissos location, also on the mountain. There's also a mountain refuge at the summit, and you can hike up to it via a 6 km path that begins in the Platanakia area. You can also see a small zoo and a café in the Platanakia area, which is a nice place for relaxing. The summit offers panoramic views of the city. The mountain is covered in chestnut, oak, beech, and fir trees. 

If you're interested in learning more about the local culture and history, you can visit the Vlatadon Monastery, which is located near the mountain. The monastery has a rich history and is a great place to learn about the area's past. The mountain is also close to the city center, and you can easily take a bus from Egnatia Street to get there. There are 32 charted paths on the mountain, so you can explore the area and find the perfect trail for your hiking or biking needs. 

Overall, Mt Chortiatis is a great place to visit for outdoor enthusiasts and those looking to explore the local culture and history. The views from the summit are stunning, and the mountain offers a range of activities and attractions for visitors.

The Railway Station on Monastiriou Street in Thessaloniki is a significant historical landmark that played a crucial role in the city's transportation development. Construction began in 1939, and it became fully operational in 1951. The station is notable for being the starting point for Thessaloniki's west and northwest suburbs, connecting the city centre with the surrounding areas. This hub has also been an entry point for tourists and locals alike, facilitating travel to and from the city.

The railway station is a testament to Thessaloniki's industrial and economic growth during the 20th century. Its construction was a response to the city's increasing population and the need for a more efficient transportation system. The station's history is deeply intertwined with the city's west walls, Byzantine and Ottoman monuments, and other archaeological sites. The temple of Aphrodite, dating back to the 6th century BC, is just one of the many historical sites located near the station.

As a solo traveler, you may appreciate the station's accessibility and the fact that it is located in the heart of the city, making it easy to explore Thessaloniki's surrounding areas. The station's proximity to other popular attractions, such as Dimokratiou Square and the Vardariou Tower, adds to its historical significance.

Visiting the Railway Station on Monastiriou Street is an excellent way to experience Thessaloniki's rich history and transportation development. You can learn about the city's industrial past, its connection to the surrounding suburbs, and its role in the region's economic growth. As a budget-conscious traveler, you can appreciate the station's affordability and its affordability, making it an excellent addition to your itinerary. As you explore the station, be sure to capture some Instagrammable moments, such as the old steam engine or the station's architecture, to share with your social media followers.
reference: The Railway Station on Monastiriou Street, which was later renamed Egnatia Street, holds historical significance as its construction began in 1939 and it became fully operational in 1951. This station is a key part of Thessaloniki's transportation development, symbolizing the city's connectivity and progress in the mid-20th century. Additionally, the presence of the old steam engine in front of the station highlights the historical evolution of transportation in the area.

(mostly old hotels) that are absolutely worth observing, as well as some of the city’s most important monuments. MUST SEE: 1.1 Kolomvou Square. This is the location of Kolomvou Archway (31, Egnatia St.) which has become a leisure hub with cafés, bars and restaurants inside. 1.2 Hamza Bey Mosque. It was built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II. It is the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle (a colonnaded yard). For many decades it housed a cinema named Alkazar. Currently there are renovation works under way. Once they are finished, it will house an exhibition of finds unearthed during the metro excavations. Right behind it you will see the City Manor which housed the Town Hall until recently. It is known at Karavan Serai as there used to be an ottoman inn here. (early 16th c.). 4th walk:']
response:
Egnatia Street holds significant historical importance in Thessaloniki as it dates back to the Roman era, connecting the city with Dyrrhachium (modern-day Durrës, Albania) and Constantinople. This ancient road has been an integral part of Thessaloniki's history, serving as a major thoroughfare for centuries.

Along Egnatia Street, you can find several notable landmarks. The street starts at Dimokratia square and ends at the TIF grounds, passing through the heart of Thessaloniki's historic centre. Some of the most remarkable buildings along this avenue are from the early 20th century, showcasing eclectic and art deco styles. These include old hotels, which are worth observing for their architectural charm.

The Kolomvou Square, located at the intersection of Egnatia Street and Antigonidon Street, is a bustling hub with cafés, bars, and restaurants. This area has become a leisure hub, making it an ideal spot for solo travelers like you to relax and socialize.

Another notable landmark is the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II. This historic mosque is a testament to the rich cultural heritage of Thessaloniki.

Egnatia Street is also home to the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, which splits the street into two parts, further highlighting its historical significance. As a solo traveler, you'll appreciate the opportunity to explore this iconic avenue, taking in the sights, sounds, and history of Thessaloniki.

For Instagram-worthy spots, Egnatia Street is a must-visit destination. The street's unique blend of ancient history, modern architecture, and lively atmosphere makes it an ideal location for capturing stunning photos and sharing your Thessaloniki experience on social media.
reference: Egnatia Street is historically significant as it has been a central avenue since the founding of Thessaloniki, originally constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC to connect Dyrrhachium with Constantinople. Along this busy shopping area, notable landmarks include Kolomvou Square, which features the Kolomvou Archway, a leisure hub with cafés and restaurants, and the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, which is unique for its peristyle and is currently undergoing renovations to house an exhibition of archaeological finds.

The Railway Station in Thessaloniki is a significant historical landmark with a rich history dating back to 1894. Built in the neoclassical style, it was the primary connection between Thessaloniki and other major cities in Greece, the Balkans, and Istanbul. For nearly a century, the station played a crucial role in the transportation of people and goods between these regions.

During World War II, the Railway Station became a tragic site when the German occupation forces forcibly relocated approximately 50,000 Jewish residents from Thessaloniki to concentration camps via trains from the station. This event remains a painful reminder of the city's dark past.

Today, the station has been repurposed as a cargo train station, but its historical significance remains. As the terminus of the west metro line, it continues to connect Thessaloniki with the rest of the country and beyond. Visitors can explore the station's architecture, which still retains much of its original neoclassical charm.

The Railway Station's historical significance extends beyond its functional role as a transportation hub. As an Instagrammable spot, it provides a chance to capture memorable photos.

Its significance extends beyond its functional role, serving as a poignant reminder of the city's complex history. As a budget-friendly option for sightseeing, the Railway Station is an excellent choice for solo travelers seeking to experience the local culture and history.

The Railway Station in Thessaloniki is a historical landmark that played a significant role in connecting the city to the rest of Greece, the Balkans, and Istanbul. Built in 1894 in the neoclassical style, it was used as a major transportation hub until the 1960s. The station was exclusively used as a cargo train station after that, but its significance lies in its history of connecting Thessaloniki to other major cities in the region.

The station was particularly notable during World War II, as it was the location where the German occupation forces mustered about 50,000 Jewish residents from March to August 1943, and then sent them by train to concentration camps. This dark period in history serves as a poignant reminder of the station's role in the city's complex past.

Today, the station is no longer used for passenger transportation, but it remains an important part of Thessaloniki's cultural heritage. The station's neoclassical architecture and historical significance make it an attractive spot for tourists and locals alike. Visitors can still see the statue of King Constantine, who entered the city in 1912, and the station's exterior side, which combines modern and classical elements.

The railway station's transportation role was significant in its time, connecting Thessaloniki to the rest of Greece and the Balkans. It was also an important hub for the city's economy and culture. Although it is no longer used for passenger transportation, the station remains an important part of Thessaloniki's history and cultural identity.

In terms of Instagrammable spots, the Railway Station is a must-visit for its unique architecture and historical significance. Visitors can take photos of the station's exterior, the statue of King Constantine, and the surrounding streets, which offer a glimpse into Thessaloniki's rich cultural heritage.

The Railway Station in Thessaloniki is a significant historical landmark that played a crucial role in connecting the city with the rest of Greece, the Balkans, and Istanbul. Built in 1939 and fully operational by 1951, it was an important transportation hub for both passenger and cargo trains. 

Located on Monastiriou Street, which was later renamed Egnatia Street, the Railway Station is situated near the city's west walls, Byzantine and Ottoman monuments, and other archaeological sites, including the temple of Aphrodite. The station was also the site of the infamous deportation of approximately 50,000 Jewish residents by the German occupation forces between March and August 1943. 

Today, the Railway Station is exclusively used as a cargo train station, but its historical significance remains. The station's location near the city center and the harbor makes it a convenient starting point for exploring Thessaloniki's attractions. 

Visitors can easily access the station by bus or on foot, and its proximity to other historical sites and landmarks makes it an ideal starting point for sightseeing tours. The station's architecture is a testament to the city's rich history, with a blend of modern and neoclassical elements.

Overall, the Railway Station in Thessaloniki is a must-visit destination for anyone interested in history, architecture, and culture. Its significance extends beyond its functional use as a transportation hub, as it serves as a poignant reminder of the city's complex past and its role in the region's history.

response:
The Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki represent the cultural heritage of Christianity and the Byzantine Empire. They are a testament to the city's rich history as one of the first towns to know the Christian religion by the Apostle Paul. The monuments, which date back to the 4th to 15th centuries, showcase the city's significant role in the Byzantine Empire and its influence on the entire Byzantine world.

These monuments include early-Christian and Byzantine churches, such as the Holy Twelve Apostles Church, built in 1310-1314 under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I. The church is considered an excellent specimen of Byzantine church-building and art, and its mural and iconography provide insight into the city's cultural heritage.

The Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki also represent the cultural heritage of the Byzantine Empire, which was a significant cultural and economic power in the Mediterranean during the Middle Ages. The monuments demonstrate the empire's artistic and architectural achievements, as well as its cultural exchange with other civilizations.

In 1988, UNESCO declared the Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki to be World Heritage Monuments, recognizing their cultural and historical significance. Today, the monuments continue to be an important part of Thessaloniki's cultural identity and a source of pride for the city's residents.

Visitors to the Byzantine monuments can experience the city's rich cultural heritage firsthand by walking through the open-air museum, which features many of the city's most significant Byzantine monuments. The monuments offer a unique glimpse into the city's history and its role in the Byzantine Empire, making them a must-visit destination for anyone interested in exploring Thessaloniki's cultural heritage.
reference: The UNESCO World Heritage site of Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki represents a significant aspect of cultural heritage, showcasing early-Christian and Byzantine monuments that were constructed during the Byzantine period (4th – 15th century). These monuments reflect the city's historical importance as a center of Christianity and its architectural achievements, influencing the entire Byzantine world.

reference_contexts:
['<1-hop>

34 1 EGNATIA STREET This central avenue has been there practically since Thessaloniki’s founding, as it is a section of the road constructed by the Romans in the 2nd c. BC, and connected Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in modern day Albania) with Constantinople. It starts at Dimokratia square (see p. 58) and ends at the TIF grounds (see p. 31) and the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, splitting in two the town’s historic centre. It is a busy shopping area with numerous remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style dating to the early 20th c. (mostly old hotels) that are absolutely worth observing, as well as some of the city’s most important monuments. MUST SEE: 1.1 Kolomvou Square. The crossroads where Egnatia Street meets Antigonidon Street is indeed a bustling one! It was named after G. Colombo, an Italian who opened a hotel there in the early 20th century. This is the location of Kolomvou Archway (31, Egnatia St.) which has become a leisure hub with cafés, bars and restaurants inside. 1.2 Hamza Bey Mosque. It was built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II. It is the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle (a colonnaded yard). For many decades it housed a cinema named Alkazar. Currently there are renovation works under way. Once they are finished, it will house an exhibition of finds unearthed during the metro excavations. Right behind it you will see the City Manor which housed the Town Hall until recently. It is known at Karavan Serai as there used to be an ottoman inn here. (early 16th c.). 4th walk:', '<2-hop>

MUST SEE: 2.1 Railway Station. It is on Monastiriou Street which is renamed at some point Egnatia Street (see p. 34). Construction began in 1939 and it became fully operational in 1951, but it was officially 66. Vardariou Tower (Top Hane). 67. Old steam engine fronting Thessaloniki’s Railway Station.']

response:
Egnatia Street is a central avenue in Thessaloniki that has been in place since the city's founding. It starts at Dimokratia Square and ends at the TIF grounds and the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, splitting the town's historic centre in two. This street is a busy shopping area with numerous remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style, dating back to the early 20th century. 

Some important places in Thessaloniki that can be found on Egnatia Street are:
- Kolomvou Square, a bustling crossroads where Egnatia Street meets Antigonidon Street, featuring a leisure hub with cafés, bars, and restaurants inside.
- Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II.
Additionally, Egnatia Street is connected to other notable landmarks such as:
- Aristotelous Street, a pedestrianised historic boulevard that ends in Egnatia Street, featuring a mix of Byzantine and European interwar period motifs.
- Electra Palace hotel, a monumental building designed by GNTO architects and now the seat of the Thessaloniki Film Festival.

Egnatia Street is a must-visit destination for anyone looking to experience Thessaloniki's rich history, culture, and shopping scene. Its unique architecture, lively atmosphere, and Instagram-worthy spots make it an ideal place to explore and discover the city's hidden gems. As a solo traveler, you'll enjoy the street's bustling energy and opportunities to meet locals, making it an excellent choice for your weekend getaway.
reference: Egnatia Street is a central avenue in Thessaloniki that has been present since the city's founding, originally constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC. It connects Dyrrhachium with Constantinople and is a busy shopping area featuring remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style from the early 20th century. Important places along Egnatia Street include Kolomvou Square, known for its bustling atmosphere and leisure spots, and the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, which is notable for its unique peristyle and ongoing renovation works.

response:
The Railway Station on Monastiriou Street is a historical landmark in Thessaloniki that has played a significant role in the city's transportation development. Built in 1939, it became fully operational in 1951. This construction timeline coincides with the expansion of the Greek railway network during the interwar period, aiming to connect major cities across the country.

The Railway Station was officially opened on Monastiriou Street, which is later renamed Egnatia Street. Its construction marked a significant improvement in the city's connectivity, facilitating the transportation of people and goods to and from Thessaloniki. The station's modern design and facilities were likely influenced by the prevailing architectural styles of the time, such as neoclassicism.

The Railway Station's historical significance extends beyond its architectural design. It also holds cultural and social importance, as it was the site of a tragic event during World War II. In 1943, the station was used to muster approximately 50,000 Jewish residents, who were then sent to concentration camps. This dark chapter in the station's history serves as a poignant reminder of the atrocities committed during the war.

Today, the Railway Station remains an essential transportation hub in Thessaloniki, serving as the terminus for the city's west metro line. Its construction timeline and historical significance underscore the city's growth and development as a major transportation center in Greece.

As a solo traveler, you can appreciate the Railway Station's historical significance and architectural design, making it an Instagrammable spot. You can also interact with locals, who may share their knowledge and insights about the station's history and cultural importance. Overall, the Railway Station on Monastiriou Street is an essential destination for anyone interested in exploring Thessaloniki's rich history and cultural heritage.
reference: The Railway Station on Monastiriou Street, which was renamed Egnatia Street, holds historical significance as a key transportation hub in Thessaloniki. Construction of the station began in 1939, and it became fully operational in 1951, marking an important development in the city's transportation infrastructure. The station's establishment coincided with a period of modernization in Thessaloniki, enhancing connectivity and facilitating travel, which was crucial for the city's growth and development.

Egnatia Street holds significant historical importance in Thessaloniki, dating back to the Roman era when it was a major road connecting the city with Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in modern-day Albania) and Constantinople. This ancient road has been preserved and remains an essential part of the city's historic center.

Notable landmarks along Egnatia Street include the Kolomvou Square, where the street meets Antigonidon Street, and the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II. The square is also home to the leisure hub, Kolomvou Archway, featuring cafes, bars, and restaurants.

Egnatia Street is lined with remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style, dating back to the early 20th century, including old hotels that are worth observing. These structures showcase the city's rich history and architectural diversity.

As a solo traveler, you'll appreciate the bustling atmosphere and variety of shops, restaurants, and cultural attractions along Egnatia Street. The street's accessibility and pedestrian-friendly design make it easy to explore on foot, allowing you to soak up the local culture and take in the historic landmarks.

For Instagrammable spots, Egnatia Street offers plenty of opportunities, from the vibrant street life to the stunning architecture. The street's summer climate and pleasant weather make it an ideal destination for a weekend getaway.

In terms of local interaction, Egnatia Street is a great place to meet locals, with many cafes and restaurants welcoming tourists. The street's proximity to the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki and the historic center makes it easy to engage with the local community and learn about the city's rich history and culture.

Overall, Egnatia Street is a must-visit destination in Thessaloniki, offering a unique blend of history, culture, and entertainment that's sure to leave a lasting impression.

Along this busy shopping area, notable landmarks include Kolomvou Square, which features the Kolomvou Archway, and the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, known for its unique peristyle and current renovation for an exhibition of archaeological finds.

['<1-hop>

65 SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS 2.4 Aretsou – Krini. These two most popular areas of Kalamaria stretch along the seafront. The facilities of the local marine sports club are here, next to Aretsou-Krini beach; there is also an open air cinema and a marina (the only one in town) with a 242-berth capacity (there are power, water and telephone services). The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas which get filled to capacity all year round. 2.5 Komninon Street. The longest part of the town’s main street is for pedestrian use only and you will find shops, cafés, small bars and restaurants along the way. This is also where you will find the area’s central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are. From the direction of the seafront, you can reach the area via I. Passalidis Street. How to get there. Bus lines 5 and 5A leave from Eleftherias square. Get off at Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] stop or at Chamodrakas stop in Aretsou area. 3', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi.
