105 Hellenic Professional Yacht Owners Association: Marina Zeas (Administration Building), 185 36 – Piraeus tel.: 210 45.26.335 fax: 210 42.80.465 website: www.hpyoa.gr MARINA The Thessaloniki Marina is located in Aretsou Kalamaria, tel.: \x072310 444.598, 2310 444.541 (Port Authority) fax: 2310 444.585 VHF: Channel 9 (24-hour service) website: www.thessaloniki-marina.gr BEACHES Go for a swim in Aretsou beach (Kalamaria, see p. 64) and the nearby beaches of Peraia, Neoi Epivates, Agia Triada (see p. 67) or in Nea Michaniona, Angelochori (see p. 68) and the beaches in Epanomi (see p. 68). A bit farther away, you can try the beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). At a 60 – 90 min. distance from the city you will reach the very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92). MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS Lagkadas Spa: Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki tel.: 23940 22.221 website: www.loutralagada.gr Nea Apollonia Spa: tel.: 23930 41.207 (Town Hall), 23930 41.510, 23930 42.151 (Spa facility) Souroti Spring (where natural mineral water is bottled): Location: Souroti, Thessaloniki tel.: 23960 41.182 (name of bottling company: Souroti A.E.), website: www.souroti.gr) Mud Therapy Spa Centre (Pikrolimni): Xylokeratia, Kilkis tel.: 23410 29.971-3 website: www.pikrolimnispa.gr TRANSPORT Buses. The urban bus service network covers all city areas. The main bus termini are at the Railway Station (see p. 58), in Venizelou Street (Eleftherias square, see p. 17), and Aristotelous square (see p. 15); also at the interchange stations in Stavroupoli (see p. 61), at K.T.E.L. (intercity bus station), IKEA (Pylaia area) and Lagkadas (see p. 93). Buses run from 5 am until midnight, yet there are certain lines running after midnight connecting major junctions. You can purchase a bus pass (one-month, three- months or an annual one) or use a ticket: the one-way basic type, the ticket valid for two trips for a 70-min. period, the ticket valid for three trips for a 90-min. period and the ticket valid for four trips for a 120-min. period, towards any direction on any bus route. You will find ticket boxes in central locations, at the interchange stations and there are also ticket machines inside the buses. Tickets must be validated on the first trip (bus routes info in Greek: tel.: 11085 website: www.oasth.gr. Cultural route: The 50 bus service runs by the city’s major historical and cultural monuments starting from the White Tower and following a circular 50 min. route. On the way, passengers can get information on the monuments using the audiovisual material and pamphlets supplied (in Greek and in English). Bus no. 22 follows a circular route in Ano Poli and Mouschounti square is the terminus. Sightseeing tours can also be taken in open top tourist buses, starting from the White Tower. It is a 70-min. tour in 8 languages. Makedonia International Airport of Thessaloniki. It is situated in Mikra area, 15 km SE of the city centre (tel. 2310 985.000). There is a bus service (no. 78 by day and no. 78N by night) connecting the airport with the Railway Station and the Intercity bus station (K.T.E.L.); the 79 bus runs from A.S. IKEA station to the airport. response:
You can visit the beaches in Chalkidiki, which are part of the region's stunning coastline. Some popular beaches to visit are:

*   Kassandra Beach: Located in the Kassandra peninsula, it's a 10 km long beach that's awarded a Blue Flag, making it a great spot for water sports and activities.
*   Sithonia Beach: This beach is located in the Sithonia peninsula and offers a more relaxed atmosphere, perfect for swimming and sunbathing.
*   Nea Vrasna Beach: This beach is located near the village of Vrasna and offers a beautiful beach with clear waters and golden sand.
*   Agios Vasileios Beach: Located in the Agios Vasileios village, this beach offers a picturesque setting with clear waters and a relaxed atmosphere.

All of these beaches are easily accessible from Thessaloniki. Here are the approximate distances:

*   Kassandra Beach: 30-40 km from Thessaloniki
*   Sithonia Beach: 35-45 km from Thessaloniki
*   Nea Vrasna Beach: 20-30 km from Thessaloniki
*   Agios Vasileios Beach: 25-35 km from Thessaloniki

You can easily reach these beaches by car or by taking a bus or taxi from Thessaloniki. Just make sure to check the opening hours and any specific regulations for each beach before you go.

These beaches offer a great combination of natural beauty, relaxation, and accessibility, making them perfect for a solo traveler looking for a budget-friendly and Instagrammable experience. So, pack your bags and head to Chalkidiki for a wonderful weekend getaway!
reference: The very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki are located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. These beaches are known for their scenic beauty and are a great destination for swimming and relaxation.

The urban bus service network covers all city areas. The main bus termini are at the Railway Station (see p. 58), in Venizelou Street (Eleftherias square, see p. 17), and Aristotelous square (see p. 15); also at the interchange stations in Stavroupoli (see p. 61), at K.T.E.L. (intercity bus station), IKEA (Pylaia area) and Lagkadas (see p. 93). Buses run from 5 am until midnight, yet there are certain lines running after midnight connecting major junctions. You can purchase a bus pass (one-month, three- months or an annual one) or use a ticket: the one-way basic type, the ticket valid for two trips for a 70-min. period, the ticket valid for three trips for a 90-min. period and the ticket valid for four trips for a 120-min. period, towards any direction on any bus route. You will find ticket boxes in central locations, at the interchange stations and there are also ticket machines inside the buses. Tickets must be validated on the first trip (bus routes info in Greek: tel.: 11085 website: www.oasth.gr. Cultural route: The 50 bus service runs by the city’s major historical and cultural monuments starting from the White Tower and following a circular 50 min. route. On the way, passengers can get information on the monuments using the audiovisual material and pamphlets supplied (in Greek and in English). Bus no. 22 follows a circular route in Ano Poli and Mouschounti square is the terminus. Sightseeing tours can also be taken in open top tourist buses, starting from the White Tower. It is a 70-min. tour in 8 languages. Makedonia International Airport of Thessaloniki. It is situated in Mikra area, 15 km SE of the city centre (tel. 2310 985.000). There is a bus service (no. 78 by day and no. 78N by night) connecting the airport with the Railway Station and the Intercity bus station (K.T.E.L.); the 79 bus runs from A.S. IKEA station to the airport. PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
Some popular beaches to visit in Chalkidiki are Aretsou, Peraia, Neoi Epivates, Agia Triada, Nea Michaniona, Angelochori, and the beaches in the Asprovalta area, Nea Vrasna, and Stavros. These beaches are located in the southern part of the peninsula, and most of them are within a 60-90 minute drive from Thessaloniki. 

Aretsou beach in Kalamaria is a great spot for swimming and is easily accessible from the city. Peraia, Neoi Epivates, and Agia Triada are also nearby, and offer a range of amenities such as restaurants, cafes, and shops. Nea Michaniona and Angelochori are a bit further away, but still within a short drive from Thessaloniki. 

The Asprovalta area is a bit farther away, but still accessible within a 1.5 hour drive from Thessaloniki. Nea Vrasna and Stavros are popular beach destinations in this area, known for their crystal-clear waters and picturesque views. 

These beaches offer a range of experiences for beachgoers, from swimming and sunbathing to water sports and scenic views. Many of these beaches are also Instagrammable spots, making them perfect for social media enthusiasts. 

Overall, Chalkidiki's beaches offer a great combination of natural beauty, amenities, and accessibility, making them an ideal destination for a weekend getaway from Thessaloniki. 

Note: I've focused on beaches within a 60-90 minute drive from Thessaloniki, as this is a reasonable travel time for a weekend getaway. However, if you're willing to drive a bit farther, the beaches in the Asprovalta area are definitely worth visiting.
reference: The popular beaches in Chalkidiki are located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. These beautiful beaches are well-known for their scenic views and are a great destination for swimming.

105 Hellenic Professional Yacht Owners Association: Marina Zeas (Administration Building), 185 36 – Piraeus tel.: 210 45.26.335 fax: 210 42.80.465 website: www.hpyoa.gr MARINA The Thessaloniki Marina is located in Aretsou Kalamaria, tel.: \x072310 444.598, 2310 444.541 (Port Authority) fax: 2310 444.585 VHF: Channel 9 (24-hour service) website: www.thessaloniki-marina.gr BEACHES Go for a swim in Aretsou beach (Kalamaria, see p. 64) and the nearby beaches of Peraia, Neoi Epivates, Agia Triada (see p. 67) or in Nea Michaniona, Angelochori (see p. 68) and the beaches in Epanomi (see p. 68). A bit farther away, you can try the beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). At a 60 – 90 min. distance from the city you will reach the very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92). MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS Lagkadas Spa: Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki tel.: 23940 22.221 website: www.loutralagada.gr Nea Apollonia Spa: tel.: 23930 41.207 (Town Hall), 23930 41.510, 23930 42.151 (Spa facility) Souroti Spring (where natural mineral water is bottled): Location: Souroti, Thessaloniki tel.: 23960 41.182 (name of bottling company: Souroti A.E.), website: www.souroti.gr) Mud Therapy Spa Centre (Pikrolimni): Xylokeratia, Kilkis tel.: 23410 29.971-3 website: www.pikrolimnispa.gr TRANSPORT Buses. The urban bus service network covers all city areas. The main bus termini are at the Railway Station (see p. 58), in Venizelou Street (Eleftherias square, see p. 17), and Aristotelous square (see p. 15); also at the interchange stations in Stavroupoli (see p. 61), at K.T.E.L. (intercity bus station), IKEA (Pylaia area) and Lagkadas (see p. 93). Buses run from 5 am until midnight, yet there are certain lines running after midnight connecting major junctions. You can purchase a bus pass (one-month, three- months or an annual one) or use a ticket: the one-way basic type, the ticket valid for two trips for a 70-min. period, the ticket valid for three trips for a 90-min. period and the ticket valid for four trips for a 120-min. period, towards any direction on any bus route. You will find ticket boxes in central locations, at the interchange stations and there are also ticket machines inside the buses. Tickets must be validated on the first trip (bus routes info in Greek: tel.: 11085 website: www.oasth.gr. Cultural route: The 50 bus service runs by the city’s major historical and cultural monuments starting from the White Tower and following a circular 50 min. route. On the way, passengers can get information on the monuments using the audiovisual material and pamphlets supplied (in Greek and in English). Bus no. 22 follows a circular route in Ano Poli and Mouschounti square is the terminus. Sightseeing tours can also be taken in open top tourist buses, starting from the White Tower. It is a 70-min. tour in 8 languages. Makedonia International Airport of Thessaloniki. It is situated in Mikra area, 15 km SE of the city centre (tel. 2310 985.000). There is a bus service (no. 78 by day and no. 78N by night) connecting the airport with the Railway Station and the Intercity bus station (K.T.E.L.); the 79 bus runs from A.S. IKEA station to the airport. Olympic Air: information – bookings tel.: 8018010101 website: www.olympicair.com Aegean Airlines: information – bookings tel.: \x078011120.000 (from a fixed line) 210 62.61.000 (from a cell phone) website: www.aegeanair.com', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
You can visit the beaches in Tagarades, Thermi area, which are close to the WaterLand amusement park. Tagarades is easily accessible from Thessaloniki by car or public transport. The beaches in this area offer a range of activities and are suitable for families. You can also visit the beaches in Nea Vrasna and Stavros, which are a bit farther away from Thessaloniki but still easily accessible by car or public transport. These beaches offer a more relaxed atmosphere and are perfect for those looking to escape the city. If you're looking for a more scenic and picturesque experience, you can visit the beaches in the Asprovalta area, which are a 60-minute drive from Thessaloniki. The beaches in this area offer stunning views and are ideal for those seeking a tranquil atmosphere. 

I recommend visiting the beaches in Tagarades and Nea Vrasna and Stavros, as they are easily accessible and offer a range of activities. If you're looking for a more secluded experience, the beaches in the Asprovalta area are a great option. Keep in mind that these beaches are a bit farther away from Thessaloniki, but the scenic views and tranquil atmosphere make them well worth the trip. 

For Instagrammable spots, the beaches in Tagarades and Nea Vrasna and Stavros are perfect, with their white sand and crystal-clear waters. The scenic views in the Asprovalta area are also great for capturing photos. 

Overall, the beaches in Tagarades, Nea Vrasna and Stavros, and the Asprovalta area are great options for those looking for easily accessible and scenic beaches in Halkidiki.
reference: Some popular beaches in Halkidiki that are easily accessible from Thessaloniki include the very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches located at a 60 to 90-minute distance from the city. Specific beaches mentioned are in the Asprovalta area, Nea Vrasna, and Stavros.

user_input: What are some popular beaches to visit in Chalkidiki, and how far are they from Thessaloniki?

tel.', 'Another option for you 
is to go swimming in the 
beautiful beaches by the 
seaside suburbs and city 
outskirts (see p. 63-69), in 
places within the regional 
unit of Thessaloniki (see p. 
91-95), and in Halkidiki (see 
p. 92). You can also visit the 
Magic Park (12th km on the 
Thessaloniki – Airport Road), 
the biggest amusement park 
in Greece, which attracts 
children, teenagers, grown-
ups and families alike  
(www.magicpark.gr); the 
WaterLand is another 
fun option as there are 
waterpools, waterslides  
of various sizes, with different 
levels of difficulty, restaurants 
and mini markets. It is 
located in Tagarades,  
Thermi area, (see p. 66).

response:
You can visit the beaches of Nea Michaniona, Angelochori, and Epanomi, which are within a short distance from Thessaloniki. These beaches offer a great combination of relaxation and scenic views. Additionally, you can also visit the beaches of Asprovalta, Nea Vrasna, and Stavros, which are about an hour's drive from Thessaloniki.

If you're looking for a more leisurely experience, you can visit the beaches of Peraia, Neoi Epivates, and Agia Triada, which are within a 30-60 minute drive from Thessaloniki. These beaches offer a great combination of relaxation and scenic views, and are perfect for a weekend getaway.

For those who prefer a more urban experience, you can visit the beaches of Aretsou, which is located near the Thessaloniki Marina and offers a great combination of relaxation and scenic views. The Thessaloniki Marina is also a great place to explore, with its shops, restaurants, and marina.

All of these beaches offer a great combination of relaxation, scenic views, and accessibility, making them perfect for a weekend getaway from Thessaloniki. Whether you're looking for a relaxing beach vacation or a more leisurely experience, there's something for everyone in Chalkidiki.

In terms of distance, here's a rough estimate of how far each beach is from Thessaloniki:

* Nea Michaniona: 45 km (28 miles), 45-60 minutes
* Angelochori: 45 km (28 miles), 45-60 minutes
* Epanomi: 50 km (31 miles), 60-75 minutes
* Asprovalta: 60 km (37 miles), 1 hour
* Nea Vrasna: 60 km (37 miles), 1 hour
* Stavros: 65 km (40 miles), 1 hour
* Peraia: 30-40 km (19-25 miles), 30-60 minutes
* Neoi Epivates: 30-40 km (19-25 miles), 30-60 minutes
* Agia Triada: 30-40 km (19-25 miles), 30-60 minutes
* Aretsou: 15-20 km (9-12 miles), 15-30 minutes

Note that these distances and times are approximate and may vary depending on traffic and other factors.
reference: The very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki are located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. Some recommended beaches include Aretsou beach in Kalamaria, as well as the nearby beaches of Peraia, Neoi Epivates, and Agia Triada.

MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS Lagkadas Spa: Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki tel.: 23940 22.221 website: www.loutralagada.gr Nea Apollonia Spa: tel.: 23930 41.207 (Town Hall), 23930 41.510, 23930 42.151 (Spa facility) Souroti Spring (where natural mineral water is bottled): Location: Souroti, Thessaloniki tel.: 23960 41.182 (name of bottling company: Souroti A.E.), website: www.souroti.gr) Mud Therapy Spa Centre (Pikrolimni): Xylokeratia, Kilkis tel.: 23410 29.971-3 website: www.pikrolimnispa.gr TRANSPORT Buses. The urban bus service network covers all city areas. The main bus termini are at the Railway Station (see p. 58), in Venizelou Street (Eleftherias square, see p. 17), and Aristotelous square (see p. 15); also at the interchange stations in Stavroupoli (see p. 61), at K.T.E.L. (intercity bus station), IKEA (Pylaia area) and Lagkadas (see p. 93). Buses run from 5 am until midnight, yet there are certain lines running after midnight connecting major junctions. You can purchase a bus pass (one-month, three- months or an annual one) or use a ticket: the one-way basic type, the ticket valid for two trips for a 70-min. period, the ticket valid for three trips for a 90-min. period and the ticket valid for four trips for a 120-min. period, towards any direction on any bus route. You will find ticket boxes in central locations, at the interchange stations and there are also ticket machines inside the buses. Tickets must be validated on the first trip (bus routes info in Greek: tel.: 11085 website: www.oasth.gr. Cultural route: The 50 bus service runs by the city’s major historical and cultural monuments starting from the White Tower and following a circular 50 min. route. On the way, passengers can get information on the monuments using the audiovisual material and pamphlets supplied (in Greek and in English). Bus no. 22 follows a circular route in Ano Poli and Mouschounti square is the terminus. Sightseeing tours can also be taken in open top tourist buses, starting from the White Tower. It is a 70-min. tour in 8 languages. Makedonia International Airport of Thessaloniki. It is situated in Mikra area, 15 km SE of the city centre (tel. 2310 985.000). There is a bus service (no. 78 by day and no. 78N by night) connecting the airport with the Railway Station and the Intercity bus station (K.T.E.L.); the 79 bus runs from A.S. IKEA station to the airport. Olympic Air: information – bookings tel.: 8018010101 website: www.olympicair.com Aegean Airlines: information – bookings tel.: \x078011120.000 (from a fixed line) 210 62.61.000 (from a cell phone) website: www.aegeanair.com', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
Halkidiki is known for its stunning beaches, and I'd like to recommend a few popular ones. 

The beaches in the Asprovalta area, Nea Vrasna, and Stavros are about a 60-90 minute drive from Thessaloniki. These beaches are popular among locals and tourists alike, offering crystal-clear waters, golden sand, and scenic views.

Another great option is the beach in Nea Michaniona, which is approximately a 30-40 minute drive from Thessaloniki. This beach is a favorite among locals, offering a relaxed atmosphere and breathtaking views of the surrounding landscape.

For a more leisurely experience, consider visiting the beaches in Epanomi, which are about a 20-30 minute drive from Thessaloniki. These beaches offer a range of amenities, including restaurants, water sports, and comfortable seating areas.

If you're looking for a more off-the-beaten-path experience, the beaches in Angelochori are worth exploring. This charming coastal town is about a 45-60 minute drive from Thessaloniki, and its beaches offer a tranquil atmosphere, crystal-clear waters, and stunning views.

Lastly, for a truly Instagrammable experience, head to the beaches in Aretsou, which are about a 45-60 minute drive from Thessaloniki. These beaches offer a range of amenities, including restaurants, water sports, and comfortable seating areas, making them a great spot for social media enthusiasts.

All of these beaches offer a range of activities, amenities, and breathtaking views, making them perfect for a leisurely weekend getaway from Thessaloniki. Enjoy your beach-hopping adventure in Halkidiki!
reference: The very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki are located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. Some recommended beaches include Aretsou beach in Kalamaria, as well as the nearby beaches of Peraia, Neoi Epivates, and Agia Triada.

(the original is kept at the 
Geology-Palaeontology Museum  
of the Aristotle University  
of Thessaloniki, see p. 38) and  
a reconstruction of the place  
it was found.
4.1  Halkidiki (also 
Chalcidice or Chalkidiki) – 
Agio Oros [Holy Mount].
Homeland of Aristotle,  
the ancient Greek philosopher, 
Halkidiki is one of the best 
and most popular tourist 
destinations in Greece with 
an important history, bustling 
tourist resorts, traditional 
villages, enchanting beaches, 
verdant mountains and an 
intense night life. Located 
south of Thessaloniki, 
Halkidiki ends in the three 
leg-shaped peninsulas named 
Kassandra, Sithonia and 
Athos. Thessalonians swarm 
in Kassandra and Sithonia for 
110.  
One of 
Halkidiki’s 
numerous 
lovely beaches.
111.  
Mount 
Athos: Agios 
Panteleimonas 
Monastery.
110']

105 Hellenic Professional Yacht Owners Association: Marina Zeas (Administration Building), 185 36 – Piraeus tel.: 210 45.26.335 fax: 210 42.80.465 website: www.hpyoa.gr MARINA The Thessaloniki Marina is located in Aretsou Kalamaria, tel.: \x072310 444.598, 2310 444.541 (Port Authority) fax: 2310 444.585 VHF: Channel 9 (24-hour service) website: www.thessaloniki-marina.gr BEACHES Go for a swim in Aretsou beach (Kalamaria, see p. 64) and the nearby beaches of Peraia, Neoi Epivates, Agia Triada (see p. 67) or in Nea Michaniona, Angelochori (see p. 68) and the beaches in Epanomi (see p. 68). A bit farther away, you can try the beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). At a 60 – 90 min. distance from the city you will reach the very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92). MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS Lagkadas Spa: Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki tel.: 23940 22.221 website: www.loutralagada.gr Nea Apollonia Spa: tel.: 23930 41.207 (Town Hall), 23930 41.510, 23930 42.151 (Spa facility) Souroti Spring (where natural mineral water is bottled): Location: Souroti, Thessaloniki tel.: 23960 41.182 (name of bottling company: Souroti A.E.), website: www.souroti.gr) Mud Therapy Spa Centre (Pikrolimni): Xylokeratia, Kilkis tel.: 23410 29.971-3 website: www.pikrolimnispa.gr TRANSPORT Buses. The urban bus service network covers all city areas. The main bus termini are at the Railway Station (see p. 58), in Venizelou Street (Eleftherias square, see p. 17), and Aristotelous square (see p. 15); also at the interchange stations in Stavroupoli (see p. 61), at K.T.E.L. (intercity bus station), IKEA (Pylaia area) and Lagkadas (see p. 93). Buses run from 5 am until midnight, yet there are certain lines running after midnight connecting major junctions. You can purchase a bus pass (one-month, three- months or an annual one) or use a ticket: the one-way basic type, the ticket valid for two trips for a 70-min. period, the ticket valid for three trips for a 90-min. period and the ticket valid for four trips for a 120-min. period, towards any direction on any bus route. You will find ticket boxes in central locations, at the interchange stations and there are also ticket machines inside the buses. Tickets must be validated on the first trip (bus routes info in Greek: tel.: 11085 website: www.oasth.gr. Cultural route: The 50 bus service runs by the city’s major historical and cultural monuments starting from the White Tower and following a circular 50 min. route. On the way, passengers can get information on the monuments using the audiovisual material and pamphlets supplied (in Greek and in English). Bus no. 22 follows a circular route in Ano Poli and Mouschounti square is the terminus. Sightseeing tours can also be taken in open top tourist buses, starting from the White Tower. It is a 70-min. tour in 8 languages. Makedonia International Airport of Thessaloniki. It is situated in Mikra area, 15 km SE of the city centre (tel. 2310 985.000). There is a bus service (no. 78 by day and no. 78N by night) connecting the airport with the Railway Station and the Intercity bus station (K.T.E.L.); the 79 bus runs from A.S. IKEA station to the airport. Olympic Air: information – bookings tel.: 8018010101 website: www.olympicair.com Aegean Airlines: information – bookings tel.: \x078011120.000 (from a fixed line) 210 62.61.000 (from a cell phone) website: www.aegeanair.com', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. You can visit the beaches in the Kassandra and Sithonia peninsulas, which are popular among locals and tourists alike. The beaches in Kassandra, such as those in Peraia and Neoi Epivates, are a bit farther away from Thessaloniki, but still accessible. 

Some popular beaches to visit in Chalkidiki are the beaches in Aretsou, Aretsou Kalamaria, and the beaches in Epanomi. Aretsou beach is located in Kalamaria, and it's a great spot for swimming and sunbathing. The beaches in Epanomi are also popular for their scenic views and water sports. 

The beaches in Kassandra and Sithonia are also worth visiting. You can try the beaches in Kassandra, such as those in Peraia and Neoi Epivates, and the beaches in Sithonia, such as those in Agia Triada and Nea Michaniona. 

The distance from Thessaloniki to these beaches varies, but generally, they are around a 1-2 hour drive away, depending on traffic. 

For example, the beaches in Kassandra are about a 1 hour drive from Thessaloniki, while the beaches in Sithonia are about a 1.5 hour drive. 

Overall, Chalkidiki has many beautiful beaches to offer, and there's something for everyone. Whether you're looking for a relaxing swim or a fun-filled day of water sports, Chalkidiki has the perfect spot for you. 

So, if you're looking for a beach vacation, Chalkidiki is definitely worth considering. With its stunning beaches, scenic views, and vibrant atmosphere, it's the perfect destination for a fun and relaxing getaway. 

And, as a bonus, the beaches in Chalkidiki are full of Instagrammable spots, making it a great destination for social media enthusiasts. 

In short, Chalkidiki's beaches are a must-visit for any beach lover. With their crystal-clear waters, golden sand, and scenic views, they're the perfect spot to soak up the sun and enjoy the beauty of nature.
reference: The popular beaches in Chalkidiki are located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. These beaches are known for their beauty and are a great destination for swimming and relaxation.

response:
You can visit the beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea Vrasna and Stavros, which are about a 60-90 minute drive from Thessaloniki. These beaches offer a great combination of natural beauty and accessibility. The Asprovalta area is particularly known for its picturesque beaches and scenic views. Nea Vrasna and Stavros offer a range of activities such as swimming, sunbathing, and water sports. 

Additionally, you can also visit the beaches in Epanomi, which is about a 30-40 minute drive from Thessaloniki. Epanomi offers a range of amenities such as restaurants, cafes, and shops, making it an ideal destination for a day trip or a short stay. The beaches in Epanomi are known for their crystal-clear waters and golden sand, making them perfect for swimming, sunbathing, and relaxation.

If you're looking for a more leisurely experience, you can visit the beaches in Nea Michaniona, Angelochori, which are about a 45-60 minute drive from Thessaloniki. These beaches offer a range of activities such as swimming, snorkeling, and kayaking, as well as scenic views and picturesque landscapes. 

All of these beaches offer a range of amenities such as restaurants, cafes, and shops, making them perfect for a day trip or a short stay. They are also easily accessible by car, making them ideal for a solo traveler.

Overall, Halkidiki offers a range of beautiful beaches that are easily accessible from Thessaloniki. Whether you're looking for a relaxing day trip or a longer stay, there's something for everyone.
reference: The very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki are located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. Some recommended beaches include Aretsou beach in Kalamaria, as well as the nearby beaches of Peraia, Neoi Epivates, and Agia Triada.

['<1-hop>

105 Hellenic Professional Yacht Owners Association: Marina Zeas (Administration Building), 185 36 – Piraeus tel.: 210 45.26.335 fax: 210 42.80.465 website: www.hpyoa.gr MARINA The Thessaloniki Marina is located in Aretsou Kalamaria, tel.: \x072310 444.598, 2310 444.541 (Port Authority) fax: 2310 444.585 VHF: Channel 9 (24-hour service) website: www.thessaloniki-marina.gr BEACHES Go for a swim in Aretsou beach (Kalamaria, see p. 64) and the nearby beaches of Peraia, Neoi Epivates, Agia Triada (see p. 67) or in Nea Michaniona, Angelochori (see p. 68) and the beaches in Epanomi (see p. 68). A bit farther away, you can try the beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). At a 60 – 90 min. distance from the city you will reach the very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92). MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS Lagkadas Spa: Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki tel.: 23940 22.221 website: www.loutralagada.gr Nea Apollonia Spa: tel.: 23930 41.207 (Town Hall), 23930 41.510, 23930 42.151 (Spa facility) Souroti Spring (where natural mineral water is bottled): Location: Souroti, Thessaloniki tel.: 23960 41.182 (name of bottling company: Souroti A.E.), website: www.souroti.gr) Mud Therapy Spa Centre (Pikrolimni): Xylokeratia, Kilkis tel.: 23410 29.971-3 website: www.pikrolimnispa.gr TRANSPORT Buses. The urban bus service network covers all city areas. The main bus termini are at the Railway Station (see p. 58), in Venizelou Street (Eleftherias square, see p. 17), and Aristotelous square (see p. 15); also at the interchange stations in Stavroupoli (see p. 61), at K.T.E.L. (intercity bus station), IKEA (Pylaia area) and Lagkadas (see p. 93). Buses run from 5 am until midnight, yet there are certain lines running after midnight connecting major junctions. You can purchase a bus pass (one-month, three- months or an annual one) or use a ticket: the one-way basic type, the ticket valid for two trips for a 70-min. period, the ticket valid for three trips for a 90-min. period and the ticket valid for four trips for a 120-min. period, towards any direction on any bus route. You will find ticket boxes in central locations, at the interchange stations and there are also ticket machines inside the buses. Tickets must be validated on the first trip (bus routes info in Greek: tel.: 11085 website: www.oasth.gr. Cultural route: The 50 bus service runs by the city’s major historical and cultural monuments starting from the White Tower and following a circular 50 min. route. On the way, passengers can get information on the monuments using the audiovisual material and pamphlets supplied (in Greek and in English). Bus no. 22 follows a circular route in Ano Poli and Mouschounti square is the terminus. Sightseeing tours can also be taken in open top tourist buses, starting from the White Tower. It is a 70-min. tour in 8 languages. Makedonia International Airport of Thessaloniki. It is situated in Mikra area, 15 km SE of the city centre (tel. 2310 985.000). There is a bus service (no. 78 by day and no. 78N by night) connecting the airport with the Railway Station and the Intercity bus station (K.T.E.L.); the 79 bus runs from A.S. IKEA station to the airport. Olympic Air: information – bookings tel.: 8018010101 website: www.olympicair.com Aegean Airlines: information – bookings tel.: \x078011120.000 (from a fixed line) 210 62.61.000 (from a cell phone) website: www.aegeanair.com', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
Halkidiki is known for its beautiful beaches, and there are several notable ones to visit. Some popular options include:

* Kassandra Beach: Located in the southern part of Halkidiki, Kassandra Beach is a favorite among tourists. It's approximately 70 km north of Thessaloniki, which takes around 1 hour and 15 minutes to drive.
* Sithonia Beach: Situated in the central part of Halkidiki, Sithonia Beach is another popular destination. It's about 60 km north of Thessaloniki, which takes around 1 hour to drive.
* Thermi Beach: Located near the city of Thermi, Thermi Beach is a great spot for swimming and sunbathing. It's approximately 40 km north of Thessaloniki, which takes around 45 minutes to drive.
* Agio Oros Beach: Also known as Holy Mount Beach, Agio Oros Beach is a beautiful beach located in the northern part of Halkidiki. It's about 90 km north of Thessaloniki, which takes around 1 hour and 30 minutes to drive.

All of these beaches offer stunning views, crystal-clear waters, and a range of amenities, making them perfect for a leisurely weekend getaway from Thessaloniki. As a solo traveler, you'll find that these beaches are relatively quiet and peaceful, allowing you to relax and enjoy the scenery.

If you're looking for an Instagrammable spot, Kassandra Beach is a great option, with its picturesque views and vibrant atmosphere. Additionally, all of these beaches offer a range of water sports and activities, such as swimming, snorkeling, and kayaking, so you can enjoy the water and soak up the sun.

Overall, Halkidiki's beaches are a must-visit destination for any traveler, and with their proximity to Thessaloniki, they're easily accessible for a quick weekend getaway.
reference: The notable beaches in Halkidiki that travelers can visit include the very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. These beaches are renowned for their scenic beauty and are a great option for those looking to enjoy a swim and relax by the sea.

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. response:
Thessaloniki's Old Town holds significant historical importance in relation to its Macedonian heritage. The area was once the centre of the Macedonian Land, as described by Herodotus, and was home to the first magnificent palaces of the Macedonian Kings. The Royal House of Argeades, a dynasty that ruled the region, was also based here. The archaeological site, which includes the Royal Tombs and the Megali Toumpa, has been included in the UNESCO World Heritage List.

The connection to the Roman Forum is that Thessaloniki was destroyed by the Romans in 168 BC and later became a deserted city. The Roman Forum, which is now part of the city's Old Town, is a testament to this historical event. The forum was likely built during the Roman period and features various monuments and structures that date back to that time. However, it's worth noting that the Roman Forum is not directly related to the Macedonian heritage, but rather is a result of the city's transformation under Roman rule.

Visitors to Thessaloniki's Old Town can explore the ruins of the Roman Forum, which are now part of the city's historic centre. The area is also home to other historical landmarks, such as the White Tower and the Nikis Avenue, which offer a glimpse into the city's rich history. While the Roman Forum is not directly connected to the Macedonian heritage, it is an important part of Thessaloniki's history and offers a unique glimpse into the city's transformation under Roman rule.

For a solo traveler looking to explore Thessaloniki's Old Town, the Roman Forum is a must-visit destination. The area is easily accessible, and the ruins are a fascinating insight into the city's history. Visitors can also explore the surrounding area, which is filled with historic landmarks and Instagrammable spots, making it an ideal destination for a budget-conscious traveler seeking familiar experiences.
reference: Thessaloniki's Old Town is significant for its Macedonian heritage as it showcases a blend of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements, reflecting the city's historical evolution. The area remained largely untouched by the 1917 great fire, preserving its original town planning and narrow alleys. This atmosphere has attracted artists and students, emphasizing its cultural importance. Additionally, the Roman Forum, which served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, connects to this heritage by highlighting the city's historical role as a significant urban center in Macedonia. The Forum's construction in the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD and its gradual abandonment after the 7th century further illustrate the layered history of Thessaloniki, linking its Macedonian roots to its Roman past.

Ever since the 4th c. BC when it was founded, 
Thessaloniki has kept its urban character and has 
remained a civic centre and the hub of that region. 
The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous

DION – VERGINA – ANCIENT PELLA

THESSALONIKI', '70
ARCHAEOLOGICAL MUSEUM 
OF THESSALONIKI
Works of art of outstanding 
value and excavated ensembles 
from the entire region of 
Macedonia are on display, 
covering all the aspects of 
private and public life in the 
area, from the prehistoric era 
to the late antiquity period. 
Exhibits are organised in six 
basic categories:
• Towards the birth of towns. 
(ground floor, room 4). The 
evidence on display shows 
that there were settlements in 
Macedonia dating to the Iron 
Age, from 1100 to 700 BC.
• Macedonia from the 7th c.  
BC until Late Antiquity. 
(ground floor, room 5). Eight 
large theme sections cover 
various aspects of private 
and public life in Macedonia 
from the archaic years, when 
the independent Macedonian 
kingdom was created, until 
the 1st – 4th c. AD, when the 
entire region was a province 
of the Roman Empire. Finds 
come mainly from excavations 
carried out in areas of central 
Macedonia.
• Thessaloniki, Metropolis 
of Macedonia. (ground 
floor, room 6). Historical and 
archaeological information 
is presented, starting from 
315 BC when the town was 
founded. There is also a 
partial reconstruction of an 
archaic temple of Ionic order, 
whose original position is yet 
unknown; it was transported 
to the area of the Temples of 
Thessaloniki during the Roman 
occupation.']

response:
Thessaloniki's Old Town is a treasure trove of historical significance, boasting a rich Macedonian heritage that dates back to the Iron Age. The city's strategic location made it a hub for various empires, including the Romans, who occupied it from the 1st to the 4th century AD. The Roman Forum, situated nearby, played a pivotal role in the city's development, with many historical landmarks and artifacts still intact.

As you wander through the Old Town, you'll discover remnants of the ancient city's Macedonian past, including the remains of the Roman-occupied city's infrastructure and architectural features. The area is also home to several museums, such as the Archaeological Museum of Thessaloniki, which showcases a vast array of artifacts from the region's prehistoric era to the late antiquity period.

One of the most iconic landmarks in the Old Town is the White Tower, which stands as a testament to the city's Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. However, its proximity to the Roman Forum makes it an essential stop for anyone interested in exploring Thessaloniki's Macedonian heritage.

In the evening, as the sun sets over the city, the Old Town transforms into a vibrant hub of activity, with locals and tourists alike gathering at the old seafront, Nikis Ave., to take in the sights and sounds. This is the perfect opportunity to immerse yourself in the local culture and meet fellow travelers who share your interests.

As you explore the Old Town, be sure to capture the Instagram-worthy moments, from the stunning architecture to the bustling streets. With its rich history, cultural attractions, and vibrant atmosphere, Thessaloniki's Old Town is an absolute must-visit destination for anyone seeking to experience the city's Macedonian heritage and connect with the local culture.
reference: Thessaloniki's Old Town is significant for its Macedonian heritage as it showcases a blend of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements, reflecting the city's diverse history. The area remained largely untouched by the 1917 great fire, preserving its original town planning and atmosphere, which has attracted artists and students. Additionally, the Roman Forum, which served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, further emphasizes the historical depth of Thessaloniki. The Forum's construction in the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD and its gradual abandonment after the 7th century highlight the city's evolution through different eras, including its Macedonian roots.

retrieved_contexts:
['6
Ever since the 4th c. BC when it was founded, 
Thessaloniki has kept its urban character and has 
remained a civic centre and the hub of that region. 
The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous 
monuments, dating to many historical periods, coexist in 
a singular and charming way and manifest Thessaloniki’s 
historical multicultural and cosmopolitan nature.
1. 
The White Tower 
area is one of the 
busiest parts of 
the city, where 
the old seafront 
(Nikis Ave.) meets 
the new (eastern) 
waterfront area 
of Thessaloniki.
DION – VERGINA – ANCIENT PELLA
PETRALONA CAVE – LAKES AREA
THESSALONIKI', '70
ARCHAEOLOGICAL MUSEUM 
OF THESSALONIKI
Works of art of outstanding 
value and excavated ensembles 
from the entire region of 
Macedonia are on display, 
covering all the aspects of 
private and public life in the 
area, from the prehistoric era 
to the late antiquity period. 
Exhibits are organised in six 
basic categories:
• Towards the birth of towns. 
(ground floor, room 4). The 
evidence on display shows 
that there were settlements in 
Macedonia dating to the Iron 
Age, from 1100 to 700 BC.
• Macedonia from the 7th c.  
BC until Late Antiquity. 
(ground floor, room 5). Eight 
large theme sections cover 
various aspects of private 
and public life in Macedonia 
from the archaic years, when 
the independent Macedonian 
kingdom was created, until 
the 1st – 4th c. AD, when the 
entire region was a province 
of the Roman Empire. Finds 
come mainly from excavations 
carried out in areas of central 
Macedonia.
• Thessaloniki, Metropolis 
of Macedonia. (ground 
floor, room 6). Historical and 
archaeological information 
is presented, starting from 
315 BC when the town was 
founded. There is also a 
partial reconstruction of an 
archaic temple of Ionic order, 
whose original position is yet 
unknown; it was transported 
to the area of the Temples of 
Thessaloniki during the Roman 
occupation.']
reference_contexts:
["<1-hop>

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. This particular atmosphere has lured intellects, artists and students who chose it for settlement in recent years. 1 \x07AGIA AIKATERINI [SAINT CATHERINE] CHURCH (see p. 12) NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. response:
Thessaloniki's Old Town holds significant historical importance, particularly in relation to its Macedonian heritage. The town's history dates back to the 4th century BC, and its multicultural nature has been shaped by various empires, including the Roman and Byzantine. The Old Town is home to numerous monuments and historical sites, showcasing the city's rich cultural diversity. 

The Thessaloniki Archaeological Museum, located in the Old Town, is a treasure trove of historical significance. It houses artifacts and exhibits that reveal the city's history, from the Iron Age to Late Antiquity. The museum's six categories of exhibits provide a comprehensive understanding of the region's history, including the city's development and the Roman Empire's influence. 

Regarding its connection to the Roman Forum, Thessaloniki's Old Town is situated near the site of the ancient city, which was an important center of Roman culture. Although the Roman Forum itself is not part of the Old Town, the nearby area features a charming waterfront, known as Nikis Avenue, which offers stunning views of the city. This area is a popular spot for tourists and locals alike, providing a glimpse into the city's rich history and cultural heritage.

Thessaloniki's Old Town is a must-visit destination for anyone interested in exploring the city's Macedonian heritage. The area is filled with historical landmarks, including the White Tower, which stands as a testament to the city's Byzantine and Ottoman past. Visitors can also explore the historic streets, lined with shops, cafes, and restaurants, offering a glimpse into the city's vibrant culture.

In summary, Thessaloniki's Old Town is a treasure trove of historical significance, offering a glimpse into the city's rich Macedonian heritage and its connection to the Roman Empire. With its stunning architecture, charming waterfront, and rich cultural diversity, the Old Town is an absolute must-visit destination for anyone traveling to Thessaloniki.
reference: Thessaloniki's Old Town is significant for its Macedonian heritage as it showcases a blend of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements, reflecting the city's diverse history. The area remained largely untouched by the 1917 great fire, preserving its original town planning and atmosphere, which has attracted artists and intellects. Additionally, the Roman Forum, which served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, connects to this heritage as it highlights the city's historical importance from ancient times through the Byzantine era, further enriching the cultural tapestry of Thessaloniki.

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. response:
Thessaloniki's Old Town is a treasure trove of historical significance, showcasing the city's rich cultural heritage. As the historic capital of Macedonia, Thessaloniki has been inhabited since ancient times, with a plethora of archaeological sites and landmarks that date back to the Roman era. The Old Town itself is a testament to the city's strategic location, which facilitated the exchange of cultures and ideas between the ancient Greeks, Romans, and other civilizations.

The Roman Forum, also known as the Forum of Thessaloniki, is a significant archaeological site located in the heart of the city. This forum was built during the Roman Empire's reign, and it played a crucial role in the city's governance and commerce. The forum is a prime example of the Roman architectural style, with its characteristic temples, basilicas, and markets. It is also an important site for the study of ancient Greek and Roman culture, providing insights into the city's economic, social, and political structures.

Thessaloniki's Old Town and the Roman Forum are deeply intertwined, as the city's history is inextricably linked to the Roman Empire. The forum was constructed during the reign of Emperor Augustus, and it became a hub for trade and commerce. The city's strategic location allowed it to become a major center for the Roman Empire, and the forum was an integral part of this network.

Visitors to Thessaloniki's Old Town can explore the Roman Forum, which offers a glimpse into the city's rich cultural heritage. The forum is surrounded by other historical landmarks, such as the Archaelogical Museum and the Church of Saint Demetrius, which further enhance the city's historical significance. Overall, Thessaloniki's Old Town and the Roman Forum are essential destinations for anyone interested in exploring the city's cultural heritage, which is deeply rooted in the Roman Empire.
reference: Thessaloniki's Old Town is historically significant as it has remained largely untouched since the 1917 great fire and showcases a blend of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements. It was settled by the Ottomans in the mid-15th century due to its favorable climate and strategic position. The Roman Forum, on the other hand, served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, with construction completed in the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD. Both sites reflect the rich cultural heritage of Macedonia, illustrating the city's evolution through different historical periods and influences.

Thessaloniki during the Roman 
occupation.']

["<1-hop>

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. This particular atmosphere has lured intellects, artists and students who chose it for settlement in recent years. 1 \x07AGIA AIKATERINI [SAINT CATHERINE] CHURCH (see p. 12) NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. response:
Thessaloniki's Old Town is a treasure trove of historical significance, particularly in relation to its Macedonian heritage. As the city's foundation dates back to the 4th century BC, it has been a hub of multiculturalism and cosmopolitanism, influenced by various empires, including the Roman, Byzantine, and Ottoman. The Old Town is home to numerous monuments and historical sites that reflect this rich heritage, such as the White Tower, which stands as a testament to the city's strategic importance during the Byzantine era.

The Roman Forum, although not an actual forum, is a significant archaeological site that played a pivotal role in the city's development. Excavations have revealed that the area was once a major commercial center, with evidence of trade and cultural exchange dating back to the Iron Age and the Roman Empire. The Roman occupation of Thessaloniki had a profound impact on the city's architecture, art, and culture, leaving a lasting legacy that can be seen in the city's many historical landmarks.

The connection between the Old Town and the Roman Forum is deeply intertwined. The Roman Forum's excavations have uncovered evidence of the city's pre-Roman settlement, including artifacts from the Iron Age. The site also showcases the city's evolution under Roman rule, with numerous artifacts and remains that highlight the cultural and commercial exchange between the Romans and the local population. In essence, the Roman Forum serves as a gateway to understanding Thessaloniki's complex history, its Macedonian heritage, and the profound impact of the Roman Empire on the city's development.

Visitors to the Old Town will find themselves immersed in a fascinating narrative of cultural exchange, artistic expression, and historical significance, making the Roman Forum an essential stop for anyone seeking to explore Thessaloniki's rich heritage. Its proximity to the White Tower and other historical landmarks only adds to its allure, providing a comprehensive understanding of the city's history and its connection to the broader Mediterranean world.
reference: Thessaloniki's Old Town is significant for its Macedonian heritage as it showcases a blend of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements, reflecting the city's diverse history. The area remained largely untouched by the 1917 great fire, preserving its original town planning and architectural features. This historical context is further enriched by the Roman Forum, which served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period. Constructed in the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD, the Forum highlights the city's importance in the region and its evolution over time, linking the Macedonian past with the Roman influence that shaped Thessaloniki's development.

['It is divided in 
three sections (cold, tepid 
and hot areas) and there is 
also a vaulted tank for heating 
water. It is widely known as the 
Paradise Baths and it went by 
that name until 1968. Right next 
to it there is a roman platform 
that is indicative of the ground 
level 2000 years ago.
1.6  Roman (Ancient) Forum
During the roman period, 
this 2-hectare area used to be 
the social and religious centre 
of the city. Construction was 
completed in two phases  
(in the mid-2nd and mid-  
3rd centuries AD) and it was 
gradually abandoned after the 
7th century. The NW section 
of the archaeological site is 
covered by a large rectangular 
square [Α] with traces of 
marble paving. In the S section 
of the square lies the largest 
part of the double underground 
Cryptoporticus [covered 
passageway] [Β] which was 
most probably used as a public 
storehouse.', '71
courtyard). Antiquities dating to 
the 2nd – 4th c. AD are divided in 
two sections: in the first one a 
reconstruction is attempted of 
a cemetery segment containing 
finds, sarcophagi and altars; 
the second one involves the 
re-creation of a Greco-roman 
house with mosaic floors on 
display and items of daily use.
• Prehistoric Macedonia. 
(basement, room 11). The 
items exhibited refer to Man’s 
first productive stages in 
Macedonia (with activities such 
as hunting, fishing, agriculture, 
stock farming, weaving, 
metallurgy). There are also 
casts of skulls belonging to 
Ouranopithecus Macedoniensis, 
an early hominid primate, as 
well as of the Man found in 
Petralona cave (see p. 92).
• Temporary exhibitions. 
The museum organises each 
year a major thematic exhibition 
and 2-5 minor ones, where 
particular aspects of every day 
life in Macedonia are treated in 
connection with the Greek and 
the Mediterranean area.
THE ROMAN FORUM 
MUSEUM
Small yet very interesting, 
this museum was inaugurated 
in 2010. A narrative of local 
excavations and information 
on the museum’s building 
stages is on display in the 
vestibule; in the main hall, 
visitors will see a depiction 
of the area’s history from the 
Hellenistic years until the 4th 
c. AD.']

The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki holds significant historical importance in relation to the city's Macedonian heritage due to its connection with the ancient city of Thessalonica, which was founded by Cassius Longinus in 315 BC. The forum was built during the Roman period, and its construction was completed in two phases in the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD. The forum's layout and architecture reflect the Roman influence on the city, and its existence showcases the city's strategic importance as a major commercial and cultural center.

The forum is also linked to the prehistoric history of Macedonia, as it was built on top of an earlier settlement. The nearby archaeological site, which includes the remains of the ancient city, provides valuable insights into the region's early development. The museum located within the forum offers a glimpse into the daily life and culture of the ancient Thessalonians, with exhibits showcasing their art, architecture, and traditions.

The forum's historical significance is further underscored by its connection to the Hellenistic and Roman periods, which had a profound impact on the region. The museum's exhibits and displays provide a comprehensive understanding of the city's history, from the Hellenistic era to the 4th century AD. The forum's preservation and restoration efforts have ensured its continued relevance as a cultural and historical landmark, allowing future generations to appreciate its significance.

In summary, the Roman Forum in Thessaloniki holds a unique position in the city's history, serving as a bridge between the ancient and modern periods. Its connection to the Macedonian heritage and the prehistoric history of the region make it an essential destination for anyone interested in exploring the city's rich cultural and historical legacy.
reference: The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki, which served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, reflects the city's Macedonian heritage. Constructed in two phases during the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD, it showcases the architectural and cultural influences of the time. The forum was gradually abandoned after the 7th century, but its remnants, including a large rectangular square and the double underground Cryptoporticus, highlight the historical significance of Thessaloniki as a key location in Macedonia.

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. response:
Thessaloniki's Old Town is a treasure trove of historical significance, showcasing the city's rich multicultural heritage. The area is characterized by a unique blend of architectural styles, reflecting the influence of various empires and cultures, including the Macedonian culture during the Ottoman period.

The Old Town's architecture is a testament to its strategic location, which made it an attractive settlement for the Ottomans in the mid-15th century. The city's walls, which date back to the 4th century BC, have been preserved, and the area within them has been inhabited since the mid-15th century. The Ottoman influence is evident in the town's layout, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as in the architectural elements, such as the mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural style, known as sachnisia.

The Old Town is also home to the iconic Saint Catherine Church, which dates back to the 19th century and is a fine example of neoclassical architecture. The church's design and location reflect the city's cultural diversity, with its proximity to the White Tower and the seafront.

The area's history is also marked by the presence of the Dönmeh, a group of converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. The Old Town's unique blend of architectural styles and cultural influences has made it an attractive destination for intellects, artists, and students in recent years.

In summary, Thessaloniki's Old Town is a historical gem, showcasing the city's rich multicultural heritage and the influence of the Macedonian culture during the Ottoman period. Its unique blend of architectural styles and cultural influences make it an Instagram-worthy destination, perfect for solo travelers and those seeking familiar experiences.
reference: Thessaloniki's Old Town is historically significant as it showcases a blend of architectural styles that reflect its Macedonian heritage and the influence of the Ottoman period. The area, which remained largely untouched by the 1917 great fire, features two and three-storey houses that exhibit mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements, known as sachnisia. This unique combination of styles, along with neoclassical and eclectic motifs, highlights the town's rich cultural history. The settlement of the Ottomans in the mid-15th century, attracted by the region's fine climate and strategic position, further contributed to the architectural landscape, making it a vibrant center for intellects, artists, and students in recent years.

["<1-hop>

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. This particular atmosphere has lured intellects, artists and students who chose it for settlement in recent years. 1 \x07AGIA AIKATERINI [SAINT CATHERINE] CHURCH (see p. 12) NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. Roman (Ancient) Forum During the roman period, this 2-hectare area used to be the social and religious centre of the city. Construction was completed in two phases (in the mid-2nd and mid- 3rd centuries AD) and it was gradually abandoned after the 7th century. The NW section of the archaeological site is covered by a large rectangular square [Α] with traces of marble paving. In the S section of the square lies the largest part of the double underground Cryptoporticus [covered passageway] [Β] which was most probably used as a public storehouse. response:
The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki is a significant historical site that showcases the city's rich Roman heritage. The forum was built during the 2nd century BC and served as a hub for commercial, social, and cultural activities. Its well-preserved architecture, including the 2nd-4th century AD Odeon, the round bath house, and the colonnaded archway, demonstrates the city's strategic location at the crossroads of ancient civilizations.

The Roman Forum's historical significance is closely tied to the architectural influences seen in Macedonia. The forum's design reflects the typical Roman layout, with a central square surrounded by shops, temples, and public buildings. The use of Corinthian-order columns and pillars, as seen in the Enchanted Ones, is characteristic of Roman architecture in the region.

The Roman Forum's connection to the architectural influences of Macedonia can be seen in the following aspects:

*   The forum's layout and design are similar to those found in other Roman cities in the Mediterranean, such as Athens and Rome.
*   The use of Corinthian-order columns and pillars is a distinctive feature of Roman architecture in the region.
*   The forum's architecture is influenced by the Hellenistic period, which was a time of cultural exchange and influence between Greece and the Roman Empire.

Overall, the Roman Forum in Thessaloniki is a significant historical site that provides valuable insights into the city's rich Roman heritage and its connection to the architectural influences of Macedonia. Its well-preserved architecture and design make it an attractive destination for tourists and scholars alike.
reference: The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki, which served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, showcases significant historical importance as it was constructed in two phases during the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD. This area reflects the architectural influences of the time, which can also be seen in the mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements present in Thessaloniki’s Old Town. The forum's gradual abandonment after the 7th century and the remnants of its structures, such as the double underground Cryptoporticus, highlight the city's rich historical tapestry, which is deeply intertwined with the broader architectural heritage of Macedonia.

['6
Ever since the 4th c. BC when it was founded, 
Thessaloniki has kept its urban character and has 
remained a civic centre and the hub of that region. 
The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous 
monuments, dating to many historical periods, coexist in 
a singular and charming way and manifest Thessaloniki’s 
historical multicultural and cosmopolitan nature.

response:
The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki holds significant historical importance in relation to the city's Macedonian heritage. The forum was built during the Roman period and was used as a civic centre and hub of the region. Although it was established by the Romans, the forum was also influenced by the city's pre-Roman inhabitants, including the Macedonians.

The forum's history dates back to the 4th century BC, when Thessaloniki was a major city in the region. The city's multicultural history, including its association with great empires, empires that also had a significant impact on the Macedonian region, is a testament to the city's strategic location. The forum's architecture and features, such as the Odeon, the round bath house, and the colonnaded archway, demonstrate the city's rich cultural heritage.

The forum's significance is further highlighted by its association with the city's history as a major centre of trade and commerce. The forum was a hub of activity, with shops, a mint, and an archive office, and was also used for cultural events. The discovery of the "Enchanted Ones" or "Stoa of the Statuettes" is a notable example of the forum's historical significance, as it provides a glimpse into the city's cultural and artistic heritage.

In terms of Macedonian heritage, the forum is significant because it reflects the city's complex history and its association with various cultures and empires. The forum's architecture and features demonstrate the city's connection to the wider Macedonian region, and its cultural significance is a testament to the city's importance as a centre of trade and commerce.

Overall, the Roman Forum in Thessaloniki is a significant historical site that holds important cultural and historical significance in relation to the city's Macedonian heritage. Its rich history, cultural features, and architectural significance make it an essential destination for anyone interested in exploring Thessaloniki's complex cultural heritage.
reference: The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki, which served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, highlights the city's Macedonian heritage. Constructed in two phases during the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD, it reflects the architectural and cultural influences of the time. The forum was gradually abandoned after the 7th century, but its remnants, including a large rectangular square and the double underground Cryptoporticus, provide insight into the historical significance of Thessaloniki as a key location in Macedonia.
